It shall be unlawful for the permittee to vary from such representations unless the permittee first makes application, as required by the provisions of this chapter, to amend the permit and such amendment is approved. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-6. - Types of signs not requiring a permit. 
This section lists sign types and forms not requiring a permit. If the sign form differs from the regulations below, a permit shall be required. All sign types not listed within this section require a permit. 
A.  Street number. A city-assigned street address number is required for all residences and establishments. It must be readable from the street and may be on the building or in the yard and may include the name of the occupant in residential only. 
B.  Contractor signs, commercial. 
1.  Description. Commercial contractor signs shall be non-illuminated, located on private property, larger than the ten (10) square feet residential contractor sign, and shall not be greater than thirty-two (32) square feet in area per sign. A commercial contractor sign may be double sided. Constructing a "V" type sign shall be allowed but each side/face may not exceed a ninety (90) degree angle of separation between the sides/faces. 
2.  Setbacks. No sign or any part thereof shall be located within ten (10) feet of any right-of-way line (not to be confused with the curb or pavement line) and within twenty (20) feet of intersecting right-of-way lines. 
3.  Sign allotment. Each appropriately zoned property shall be entitled to a minimum of one (1) commercial contractor sign. For each property line abutting existing street frontage an additional sign is allowed, subject to the regulations herein. The maximum number of signs shall not exceed the total sides fronting existing public streets. Each additional sign allowable for more than one (1) street frontage must be placed on separate street sides, and no stacking of signs on one (1) or two (2) particular street frontages shall be permitted. A minimum distance of one hundred (100) linear feet shall be maintained between commercial contractor signs placed on separate street frontages. Tracts or lots of three (3) acres or larger may be permitted for more than one (1) contractor sign on one (1) frontage; provided that each sign maintain a minimum interval of five hundred (500) linear feet between signs. Not more than four (4) signs shall be allowed on one (1) lot or tract, regardless of the size of the lot or tract. A tract exceeding three (3) acres on multiple street frontages will also be subject to a maximum of four (4) signs. Commercial contractor signs are allowed depending on the zoning district(s), therefore commercial contractor signs may be permitted in NC, DN, DT, GC, IN, BP, and FR districts. If there are commercial contractor signs located on a particular tract or lot there shall not be an allowance for any other realtor signs on the same property. 
C.  Contractor signs, residential. Shall be non-illuminated, located on private property, and shall not be greater than ten (10) square feet in area. Residential realtor signs shall be limited to a single sign per property, unless one (1) of the following conditions apply: properties zoned rural estate district (RE) or existing neighborhood zone district (ENZ.1) shall be allotted a maximum to two (2) residential realtor signs, or any lot with more than one (1) property line abutting existing street frontage an additional sign shall be allowed, subject to the regulations herein. Signs will not be placed so as to create a traffic hazard, as determined by city staff. Temporary banner signs or other similar non-rigid sign material prohibited from being utilized. 
D.  Real estate signs, commercial. 
1.  Description. Commercial real estate signs shall be non-illuminated, located on private property, and is larger than the ten (10) square foot residential realty sign, and shall not be greater than thirty-two (32) square feet in area per sign. A commercial realty sign may be double sided. Constructing a "V" type sign shall be allowed but each side/face may not exceed a ninety (90) degree angle of separation between the sides/faces. 
2.  Setbacks. No sign or any part thereof shall be located within ten (10) feet of any right-of-way line (not to be confused with the curb or pavement line) and within twenty (20) feet of intersecting right-of-way lines. 
3.  Sign allotment. Each appropriately zoned property shall be entitled to a minimum of one (1) commercial realtor sign. For each property line abutting existing street frontage an additional sign is allowed, subject to the regulations herein. The maximum number of signs shall not exceed the total sides fronting existing public streets. Each additional sign allowable for more than one (1) street frontage must be placed on separate street sides, and no stacking of signs on one (1) or two (2) particular street frontages shall be permitted. A minimum distance of one hundred (100) linear feet shall be maintained between commercial realtor signs placed on separate street frontages. Tracts or lots of three (3) acres or larger may be permitted for more than one (1) real estate sign on one (1) frontage; provided that each sign maintain a minimum interval of five hundred linear (500) feet between signs. Not more than four (4) signs shall be allowed on one (1) lot or tract, regardless of the size of the lot or tract. A tract exceeding three (3) acres on multiple street frontages will also be subject to a maximum of four (4) signs. Commercial realtor signs are allowed depending on the zoning district(s), therefore commercial realty signs may be permitted in NC, DN, DT, GC, IN, BP, and FR districts. If there are commercial realtor signs located on a particular tract or lot there shall not be an allowance for any other realtor signs on the same property. A commercial realty sign may be affixed to a building or structure on the property, including walls or permanent fences. 
4.  Height. Maximum height is limited to ten (10) feet. 
5.  Duration and permitting. Commercial real estate signs must be removed by fourteen (14) days after sale or lease of the property is final. Failure to comply will result in the city removing and disposing of the sign in accordance with the provisions in this Code. 
6.  [Prohibited materials.] Temporary banner signs or other similar non-rigid sign materials are prohibited. 
E.  Residential real estate signs. Shall be non-illuminated, located on private property, and shall not be greater than ten (10) square feet in area. Residential realtor signs shall be limited to a single sign per property, unless one (1) of the following conditions apply: properties zoned rural estate district (RE) or existing neighborhood zone district (ENZ.1) shall be allotted a maximum to two (2) residential realtor signs, or any lot with more than one (1) property line abutting existing street frontage an additional sign shall be allowed, subject to the regulations herein. Signs will not be placed so as to create a traffic hazard, as determined by city staff. Temporary banner signs or other similar non-rigid sign material prohibited from being utilized. 
F.  Political signs. Political signs shall not exceed thirty-six (36) square feet in area. The placing of political signs on city property is specifically prohibited. The placing of political signs on private property without the permission of the property owner is prohibited. The person running for office and/or political party/group placing a political sign is responsible for compliance with these provisions. 
G.  Garage sale signs. Garage sale type signs in residential areas shall not exceed four (4) square feet in face area. They may not be illuminated, may not be erected earlier than two (2) days preceding the sale and shall be removed within two (2) days following the sale. Signs will show the date(s) of the sale. No permit is required for the sign itself; however, a permit is required to conduct a garage sale. Garage sales signs are only allowed upon the premises where the sale is occurring. 
H.  Sponsorship signs. Off-premise signs may be placed in parks to provide advertising for projects of nonprofit organizations such as little league, softball, soccer and horseshoe pitching arena, etc. Location of signs shall be within the activity area and shall not exceed the size of four (4) feet in height and eight (8) feet in length. No specific individual permit is required for each such sign, however, the organization or project must have prior approval by the city manager or designee, or city council. 
I.  "Open" sign. Open/closed business signs and neon open/closed business signs within a window of a business or attached to the exterior of the business shall not be counted as sign square footage for a building allotment. An "open" sign shall be limited to four (4) square feet. 
J.  Miscellaneous signs. No trespassing or posted property type signs or signs containing political speech shall not exceed four (4) square feet in the area. Signs placed with the intent of warning or advising the public of possible danger will be allowed on private property, but shall not exceed eight (8) square feet in face area. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-01B , § II.D, 1-15-2019)  
Sec. 20-7. - Detached signs. 
This section governs the regulation of all forms of freestanding (detached) signage within the city and its ETJ. No sign may be erected, structurally changed, refaced, or reconstructed in whole or part, within the city without a permit having been first obtained. Monument signs are the preferred sign form in the city, therefore these regulations seek to incentivize the erection of monument signs in the city. 
A.  General requirements. 
1.  In order to prevent a new sign from visually obstructing existing signs, all new signs must be erected so as to maintain a seventy-five (75) foot separation between other previously erected signs regardless of the sign type. The specific distance separation requirement does not apply to directional signs or temporary detached signs that are placed to provide wayfinding to and within a site; however these signs must be placed to not visually obstruct other signs or traffic sight lines and accessibility to and from the site. 
B.  Monument signs. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a ground mounted detached monument. 
2.  Maximum size and height. Based on the geographic location of the property, all monument signs shall be regulated to a classification of either highway or non-highway and be regulated to the following: 
Table B.2. 
Monument Sign sizes and height 
	Highway 	Non-Highway 
Sign surface area 	70 sq. ft. maximum 	50 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	90 sq. ft. maximum 	70 sq. ft. maximum 
Width 	14 ft. maximum 	12 ft. maximum 
Height 	8 ft. maximum 	8 ft. maximum 
 
The specified above maximums regulate the largest size or height authorized, unless the sign complies with the provisions of subsection B.3. 
3.  Size and height bonus allowance. 
a.  Monument signs shall be allowed an increase in size and height in accordance with the table below if placement of the sign is made further from adjoining right-of-way than the minimum setback established in subsection B.2. The allowance ratio in the table shall be a specified amount of additional setback distance (example: one (1) ft.) from the prescribed sign setback, for a specified amount of additional size and/or height authorized to be incrementally added to the sign for each increment of specified distance from the prescribed setback. The height and size allowances can be incrementally gained, but shall not exceed the maximum height and size in tables B.3.b. or B.3.c. Based on the geographic location of the property, all monument signs shall be regulated to a classification of either highway, table B.3.b. or non-highway, table B.3.c. 
Formula: additional unit allowed per foot of setback. 
b.  Highway, size and height ratios. 
Table B.3.b. 
Highway 
	Allowance Ratio 	Maximum Size 
Sign surface area 	5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	100 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	10 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	130 sq. ft. maximum 
Height 	1 ft. height per 1 ft. setback 	12 foot maximum 
Width 	None 	None 
 
;adv=6;c.  Non-highway, size and height ratios. 
Table B.3.c. 
Non-Highway 
	Allowance Ratio 	Maximum Size 
Sign surface area 	2.5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	70 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	100 sq. ft. maximum 
Height 	1 ft. height per 2 ft. setback 	10 ft. maximum 
Width 	None 	None 
 
4.  Allocation. One (1) monument sign per lot or tract is permitted unless: 
a.  A lot has continuous lot frontage on three (3) improved streets and in such case shall be entitled to two (2) additional monument signs shall be permitted, subject to the signs being placed on separate frontages, and a minimum two-hundred (200) feet apart, or; 
b.  A lot or tract has an excess of five-hundred (500) feet of continuous linear lot frontage on a single street and in such case shall be allowed an additional monument sign for each five-hundred (500) feet of frontage with a minimum of three-hundred and fifty (350) feet between each sign. 
c.  In all the above cases, no more than a total of three (3) monument signs shall be allowed per lot. 
5.  Setback requirements. 
a.  Monument signs shall be subject to a minimum ten (10) foot setback. 
b.  Monument signs shall be setback a minimum of fifteen (15) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines. 
6.  Separation requirement. All monument signs must maintain a distance of seventy-five (75) feet from other detached signs. 
7.  Design. 
a.  The monument shall be a minimum of forty (40) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) to match the building(s). 
b.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located at an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street on which the building fronts. 
c.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached or printed directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
d.  Signs proposing to use other equivalent materials than required above consistent with the building architecture or overall sign design may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
8.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
9.  Additional. If a sign is located in a public utility easement, the owner of the property is responsible for removal, relocation or replacement at a utility company's request or upon request of the city. 
10.  Electronic sign allowance. A single electronic message sign is allowed to be erected in combination with only one (1) monument sign on a property regardless of the number of monument signs allowed. Electronic message signs constructed or installed in combination with a monument sign must comply with the electronic message sign, monument standards herein. 
11.  Monument sign bonus/incentive. Any property that erects or maintains a monument sign consistent with these regulations shall receive a twenty-five (25) percent square footage bonus to the overall allotment of signage attached to the building. 
C.  Monolith sign. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a sign type that allows more height, yet is limited to narrower width. 
2.  Maximum size and height. Based on the geographic location of the property, all monolith signs shall be regulated to a classification of either highway or non-highway and be regulated to the following: 
Table C.2. 
Monolith Sign sizes and height 
	Highway 	Non-Highway 
Sign surface area 	70 sq. ft. maximum 	50 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	110 sq. ft. maximum 	80 sq. ft. maximum 
Width 	8 ft. maximum 	8 ft. maximum 
Height 	14 ft. maximum 	10 ft. maximum 
 
The specified above maximums regulate the largest size or height authorized, unless the sign complies with the provisions of subsection C.3. 
3.  Size and height bonus allowance. 
a.  Monolith signs shall be allowed an increase in size and height in accordance with the table below if placement of the sign is made further from adjoining right-of-way than the minimum set back established in subsection C.2. The allowance ratio in the table shall be a specified amount of additional setback distance (example: one (1) ft.) from the prescribed sign setback, for a specified amount of additional size and/or height authorized to be incrementally added to the sign for each increment of specified distance from the prescribed setback. The height and size allowances can be incrementally gained, but shall not exceed the maximum height and size in tables C.3.b. or C.3.c. Based on the geographic location of the property, all monolith signs shall be regulated to a classification of either highway, table C.3.b. or non-highway, table C.3.c. additional unit allowed per foot of setback. 
b.  Highway, size and height ratios. 
Table C.3.b. 
Highway 
	Allowance Ratio 	Maximum Size 
Sign surface area 	5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	120 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	10 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	160 sq. ft. maximum 
Height 	1 ft. height per 1 ft. setback 	20 ft. maximum 
Width 	None 	None 
 
c.  Non-highway, size and height ratios. 
Table C.3.c. 
Non-Highway 
	Allowance Ratio 	Maximum Size 
Sign surface area 	2.5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	70 sq. ft. maximum 
Gross surface area 	5 sq. ft. per 1 ft. setback 	100 sq. ft. maximum 
Height 	1 ft. height per 2 ft. setback 	10 ft. maximum 
Width 	None 	None 
 
4.  Allocation. One (1) monolith sign per lot or tract is permitted except that: 
a.  A lot with continuous lot frontage on three (3) improved streets is entitled two (2) additional monolith signs provided that the signs are placed on separate frontages, with a minimum separation of two-hundred (200) feet, address number(s) are only required to be placed on sign(s) fronting the street of the property represented by the sign; monolith signs size and height shall comply with the requirement for which the sign faces or is abutting, highway or non-highway as stated herein; 
b.  A lot or tract that has an excess of five-hundred (500) feet of continuous linear lot frontage on a single street shall be allowed an additional monolith sign for each five-hundred (500) feet of frontage with a minimum of three-hundred and fifty (350) feet of separation between each sign. 
c.  Monolith signs must conform to the size and height limitations based on their location fronting a highway or non-highway. 
d.  In all the above cases, no more than a total of three (3) monolith signs is authorized per lot. 
5.  Setback requirements. 
a.  Monolith signs shall be subject to a minimum ten (10) feet setback. 
b.  Monolith signs shall be setback a minimum of fifteen (15) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines. 
6.  Separation requirement. All monolith signs shall be erected so as to maintain a distance of seventy-five (75) feet from other detached signs. 
7.  Design. 
a.  Monolith signs shall be a minimum of forty (40) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) matching the building(s) that they represent. 
b.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located at an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street on which the building represented by the sign fronts. 
c.  Architectural accent. Monolith signs shall include architectural accents into the sign design. Design elements from the corresponding buildings or project architectural features present in the development shall be included in the sign design. If there are no notable architectural features or attributes associated with the development then one (1) must be added to the sign design to improve the character of the sign. Examples of how this may be achieved is by the addition of a roof canopy to resemble a tower or arched metalwork capping the sign. Each sign is unique and architectural accent to these signs is meant to improve the sign form. 
d.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached or printed directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
e.  Signs proposing to use other equivalent materials than required above consistent with the building architecture or overall sign design may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
8.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
9.  Relocation in utility easement. If located in a public utility easement, the owner of the property is responsible for removal, relocation or replacement at a utility company's or city's request. 
10.  Monolith sign bonus/incentive. Any property that erects or maintains a monolith sign consistent with these regulations is entitled to receive a twenty (20) percent square footage bonus to the overall allotment of signage attached to the building. 
D.  Monument sign, multi-tenant. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a multi-tenant center through the use of a ground mounted detached monument. 
2.  Maximum size and height. 
a.  Sign surface area. Tenant text and logo panels shall be no more than one-hundred and forty (140) square feet total; an additional five (5) feet of sign square footage may be added to the overall sign square footage for each additional one (1) foot of setback distance that the sign is located from adjoining right-of-way; however, the maximum square footage shall not exceed two-hundred (200) square feet. 
b.  Gross area. The gross area of a monument sign, multi-tenant monument sign shall not exceed two-hundred and forty (240) square feet total; an additional ten (10) feet of gross square footage may be added to the overall gross square footage of the sign for each additional one (1) foot of additional setback distance that the sign is located the adjoining right-of-way. However, the maximum square footage shall not exceed three-hundred (300) square feet. 
c.  Maximum height. The monument shall be no more than twenty (20) feet in height. An additional one (1) foot of sign height may be added to the overall height of the sign for each additional one (1) foot of additional setback distance that the sign is located from adjoining right-of-way; however, the maximum height shall not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
d.  The multi-tenant center name is required to be displayed on the sign and shall be no more than forty (40) square feet and shall not be counted as part of the sign surface area specified in subsection D.2.a. 
e.  The monument shall be no greater than sixteen (16) feet wide. 
3.  Applicability. Lots or tracts on a highway are authorized a monument sign, multi-tenant according to the terms and conditions set out herein. A tenant space means a suite or building with four (4) or more separate building entrances functioning as separate businesses. Subdivided spaces or rented rooms within a larger space or building do not qualify as separate tenant space for the purpose of being eligible for a monument sign, multi-tenant sign. In order to qualify for a monument sign, multi-tenant sign properties must contain businesses that meet the definition of tenant space described in this section and one (1) of the following criteria: 
a.  A lot or tract must have three (3) or more tenants in separate, rentable tenant spaces with a minimum building square footage of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet; or 
b.  Lot or tract has two (2) or more buildings, of a minimum combined square footage of eighteen thousand (18,000) square feet, with four (4) or more businesses each with separate entrances; or 
c.  Lot or tract has a building of sixty thousand (60,000) square feet or more; or 
d.  Lot or tract has more than twelve (12) businesses each with a separate entrance; or 
e.  Lot or tract has more than eighteen (18) businesses located on the premises. 
4.  Allotment. One (1) monument sign, multi-tenant per lot or tract is permitted unless; 
a.  The lot or tract has lot frontage on three (3) improved streets and one (1) or more additional driveway access points into the complex then an additional monument sign shall be permitted for a maximum of two (2) additional monument signs, at each driveway access location so long as the signs being placed on separate frontages, with a minimum of two-hundred (200) feet of separation. However, if the lot has lot frontage on three (3) improved streets, but does not have additional driveway access points to the separate street frontages, then two (2) additional monument signs shall be permitted, subject to the signs being placed on separate frontages, with a minimum separation of two-hundred (200) feet apart; or, 
b.  A lot or tract that has an excess of five-hundred (500) feet of continuous linear lot frontage on a highway shall be allowed an additional monument sign, multi-tenant for each five-hundred (500) feet of frontage with a minimum separation of three-hundred and fifty (350) feet between each sign. 
c.  In all the above cases, no more than a total of three (3) monument signs, multi-tenant or monument signs shall be allowed per lot or development. 
5.  Setback requirements. Monument sign, multi-tenant must front a highway and shall be subject to a minimum ten (10) foot setback from the property/lot line; and twenty (20) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines. 
6.  Design. 
a.  Monument signs, multi-tenant shall be constructed with a minimum of fifty (50) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) to match the building(s) that they represent. 
b.  Use of tenant panels for the purpose of providing contact information for leasing space at the multi-tenant center is authorized. 
c.  Architectural accent. Monument signs, multi-tenant shall include architectural accents into the sign design. Design elements from the corresponding building or project architectural features present in the development is required. If there are no notable architectural features or attributes associated with the development, then one (1) must be added to the sign design to improve the character of the sign. An example of how this may be achieved is by the addition of a roof canopy to resemble a tower or arched metalwork capping the sign. Each sign is unique and architectural accent to these signs is meant to improve the sign form. 
d.  All text and logos shall be uniform in color, material and lighting. The use of additional colors for minor accents may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
e.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting a street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located at an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. An address may be added to sign support poles or other vertical elements of the sign. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street on which the building represented by the sign fronts. 
f.  All letters and numbers shall be stencil cut or typeset graphics, and address numbers shall be attached or printed directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
g.  Signs proposing to use other equivalent materials than required above consistent with the building architecture or overall sign design may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
7.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
8.  Relocation in utility easement. If a monument sign, multi-tenant is located in a public utility easement, the owner of the property is responsible for removal, relocation or replacement of the sign at a utility company's or city's request. 
9.  Landscape. A minimum of one hundred (100) square feet of the ground surrounding the base of each sign under this section shall be landscaped in a manner that does not conflict with other provisions of this Code. Landscaping shall be installed and maintained so that the visibility of the address numbers is not obstructed. 
E.  Freestanding or pole signs. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a freestanding sign or pole sign. 
2.  Maximum size. Freestanding and pole signs is allowed an area equal to one (1) square foot to each two (2) linear foot of building front, not to exceed one hundred (100) square feet. A minimum of thirty-two (32) square feet is authorized regardless of building front. 
3.  Maximum height. Freestanding or pole signs shall be no more than twenty (20) feet high. 
4.  Minimum height. Freestanding or poles signs shall have a minimum height of eight (8) feet from the ground to the base of the sign. 
5.  Allocation. One (1) freestanding or pole sign per lot or tract is authorized only for highway properties. 
6.  Setback requirements. Freestanding or pole signs shall be subject to a ten (10) foot setback from the adjoining right-of-way; and thirty-five (35) feet from intersecting right-of way lines. 
7.  Separation requirement. All freestanding/pole signs must maintain a distance of seventy-five (75) feet from one another. 
8.  [Panel space.] Each tenant space within a multi-tenant or strip center shall have one (1) panel on the property's single allotted detached sign. 
9.  Design. 
a.  Freestanding/pole signs shall be supported by a one (1) of the two (2) following systems: 
i.  Single vertical pole shall be cladded or skirted from the base/ground to the sign frame. Cladding or skirting shall be one (1) or a combination of the following materials; metal/aluminum panels or plastic clad panels with a steel frame assembly, stucco finish, masonry, or stone. Cladding shall be a minimum width of thirty (30) percent of the sign frame width mounted at the top of the pole, however the cladding shall not exceed six (6) feet in width, or; 
ii.  Two (2) vertical support poles or columns shall support the sign. Columns or posts shall be set apart or separated by a minimum distance of fifty (50) percent to eighty (80) percent of the total sign frame width mounted on the support poles. Columns or posts shall have an architectural horizontal connecting element spanning the distance between the posts that adds character to the structure. 
b.  Any exposed support poles or columns shall be painted a flat black. 
c.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. At minimum the address number must be displayed. If the sign is located near the corner of the property then the street name must be on the sign in addition to the address number. An address may be added to sign support poles or other vertical elements of the sign. 
d.  All text and logos shall be consistent with the sign's theme, such as the use of uniform in color, material, and lighting. The use of additional colors for minor accents may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
e.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
f.  Signs proposing an alternative designs utilizing other materials or colors may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
10.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
11.  [Freestanding/pole signs.] Freestanding/pole signs are prohibited on properties within the city, except those with frontage on highways. 
F.  Directional signs. 
1.  Purpose. To identify the entrance/exit to a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a detached directional sign. 
2.  Maximum size. Ten (10) square feet maximum. 
3.  Maximum height. Four (4) feet. 
4.  Allocation. One (1) per driveway/entrance/exit to business/development. 
5.  Setback requirements. Directional signs shall be subject to a five (5) foot setback, unless the directional sign is less than three (3) feet in height in which case, then a zero (0) setback shall apply. 
6.  Design. 
a.  Directional signs shall be erected on a solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) base to match the building(s), and shall not be mounted on a pole(s). 
b.  No goods or services for sale or other advertising may be displayed on a directional sign. 
c.  Directional signs may include but are not specifically limited to arrows, words, or logos. 
d.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
e.  Signs proposing to use alternative materials consistent with the building architecture may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
7.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
G.  Retaining wall sign. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a detached sign mounted on a retaining wall. 
2.  Maximum size. Surface area shall be no more than forty (40) square feet; alternative sign sizes may be considered by the planning and zoning commission up to a maximum of one hundred (100) square feet, this is based there being a wide variation of potential retaining wall configurations, such as the height, size, and location. 
3.  Maximum height. The retaining wall sign shall not project above the top of the retaining wall it is constructed upon. 
4.  Allocation. One (1) retaining wall sign per lot or tract is permitted. 
5.  Setback requirements. Retaining wall signs shall be subject to a zero foot setback, if the retaining wall is at a zero (0) setback from the property/lot line, due to the retaining wall sign being required to be attached to a retaining wall; and five (5) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines if the retaining wall is less than five (5) feet height, should the retaining wall be over five (5) feet in height then the sign shall be prohibited from being attached, in such case a minimum fifteen (15) foot setback shall apply. 
6.  Design. 
a.  The retaining wall shall be a minimum of fifty (50) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) to match the building(s) for a minimum of ten (10) feet to each side of the surface area of the sign. 
b.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located near an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street which the building represented by the sign fronts. 
c.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached or printed directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
d.  Signs proposing to use alternative materials consistent with the building architecture may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
7.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is authorized. 
8.  Additional. If located in a public utility easement, the owner of the property is responsible for removal, relocation or replacement at a utility company's or city's request. 
H.  Wall sign. 
1.  Purpose. To identify a building, business, multifamily complex, or residential subdivision through the use of a detached sign mounted on a wall. 
2.  Maximum size. Shall be no more than thirty (30) square feet; alternative sign sizes may be considered by the planning and zoning commission up to a maximum of eighty (80) square feet, this is based there being a wide variation of potential wall configurations, such as the height, size, and location. 
3.  Maximum height. A wall sign shall not project above the top of the wall it is constructed upon. 
4.  Allocation. One (1) wall sign per lot or tract is permitted. 
5.  Setback requirements. Wall signs shall be subject to a zero (0) foot setback, if the wall is at a zero (0) setback from the property/lot line, due to the wall sign being required to be attached to a wall; and ten (10) feet from intersecting right-of-way lines if the wall is less than four (4) feet in height, should the retaining wall be over four (4) feet in height then the sign shall be prohibited from being attached, in such case a minimum twenty-five (25) foot setback shall apply. In no case shall a wall or the wall sign create a vision obstruction that would conflict with other city ordinances. 
6.  Design. 
a.  The wall shall be a minimum of fifty (50) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) to match the building(s), and a minimum of one-hundred (100) percent solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) for a minimum of ten (10) feet to each side of the surface area of the sign. 
b.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located near an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street on which the building represented by the sign fronts. 
c.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached or printed directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
d.  Signs proposing to use other equivalent materials than required above consistent with the building architecture or overall sign design may be approved by the city manager or designee. 
7.  Lighting. Internal sign illumination, individual letter internal illumination, or external ground lighting angled at the sign face is allowed. 
8.  Additional. If located in a public utility easement, the owner of the property is responsible for removal, relocation or replacement at a utility company's or city's request. 
I.  Multi-lot shared signage. 
1.  Purpose. To identify buildings, businesses, or multifamily complexes located on adjacent lots through the use of a single detached sign. 
2.  Applicability. In order to qualify for multi-lot shared signage, the properties must be adjacent to each other, have frontage on the same roadway, and be able to meet the locational requirement set out herein. 
3.  Requirements. 
a.  Permitted sign types. Multi-lot shared signage is limited to monument, monolith, and freestanding or pole sign types. Electronic message signs are not permitted as multi-lot shared signage. 
b.  Allocation. Except as provided in subsection d., only one (1) multi-lot shared sign is permitted per site in lieu of individual property having separate detached signage. Additionally, each property or business may be represented on only one (1) multi-lot shared sign. 
c.  Location requirements. The property(s) on which the sign is not located must have shared vehicular access with the property on which the sign is located or have a driveway entrance within one hundred (100) feet of and on the same street as the shared sign. 
d.  Separation requirements. Multi-lot shared signage must be separated a minimum of seventy-five (75) feet from another detached sign on a separate property and a minimum of five hundred (500) feet from another detached sign on any of the properties included on the shared sign. 
e.  Design standards. The sign must meet the design requirements of the applicable sign type (monument signs section 20-7.B, monolith signs section 20-7.C, and freestanding or pole signs section 20-7.E) except the maximum size and height requirements as outlined herein. 
f.  Maximum size and height. The maximum size and height allowances for multi-lot shared signs may be increased as follows: 
i.  Multi-lot shared monument signs may be increased in height by one (1) foot and increased in square footage by thirty (30) percent from that prescribed in section 20-7.B. 
ii.  Multi-lot shared monolith signs may be increased in height by two (2) feet and increased in square footage by thirty (30) percent from that prescribed in section 20-7.C. 
iii.  Multi-lot shared freestanding or pole signs may be increased in height by one (1) foot and increased in square footage by thirty (30) percent from that prescribed in section 20-7.E. 
4.  Signage forfeiture. The shared sign shall count as one of the detached signs permittable under this code for each of the properties included on the sign. Additionally, the monument sign bonus/incentive outlined in section 20-7.B.11 shall not be applicable to the property(s) on which the sign is not located. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , § II.D, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-8. - Electronic signs. 
This section governs the regulation of all permanent forms of electronic signage within the city and its ETJ. No sign may be erected, structurally changed or reconstructed in whole or part, within the city without a permit having been first obtained. 
A.  General regulations. 
1.  The city may order a sign's brightness reduced or other operational characteristics altered if the city finds that the sign interferes with or poses a traffic safety hazard to the operation of vehicles. Upon permitting of a sign the city shall require submittal of technical specifications of the sign's design to review to ensure it does not pose a hazard to the public's health, safety, or welfare. 
2.  All electronic message signs shall be turned off or shall display a blank screen when malfunctioning. 
3.  Brightness standards. The brightness standards are applicable to all forms of electronic message signs in the city. 
a.  All such signs shall be equipped with light sensing devices or a scheduled dimming timer that will automatically dim the intensity of the light emitted by the sign during ambient low-light conditions and at night so that the sign does not exceed the maximum brightness levels allowed in this section. 
b.  Maximum brightness shall not exceed seven thousand (7,000) nits when measured from the sign's face at its maximum brightness during daylight hours and shall not exceed one thousand (1,000) nits when measured from the sign's face at its maximum brightness at night. 
c.  If such sign is located within one hundred (100) feet of a property with residential zoning, the sign must be oriented such that no portion of the electronic sign face is visible from a residentially-zoned property or the brightness is reduced to no more than two hundred fifty (250) nits at night. 
d.  Prior to the issuance of a permit for such sign, the applicant shall provide written certification from the sign manufacturer that the light intensity has been factory preset not to exceed the levels specified above. 
B.  Electronic message sign, monument. 
1.  Allocation. One (1) allowed per property. None allowed attached to buildings/structures. 
2.  Maximum size. Shall not exceed twenty (20) square feet per side. 
3.  Form. Limited to not more than two (2) sides one (1) sign face per side. 
4.  Messaging standard. Monument electronic message signs must only display all messages as a static or fixed message/image of the entire screen/message board area for each message/image displayed. Static or fixed messages/images must be displayed a minimum of eight (8) seconds before rotating or displaying the next message. Scrolling, blinking, or other forms of moving text is prohibited. 
5.  Color form standard. Monument electronic message signs shall be limited to a black background, and a single uniform text and/or graphic color, being red, amber, white, blue, or green. All programmed messages the sign displays must be displayed utilizing the single selected text/graphic color. The selected message display color must be indicated at the time of permit application, and once selected and permitted, can only be altered by a permit application to amend the Sign's permitted function to another color type. A variation or combination of text/message colors of the messaging is prohibited. Flashing, blinking, or other forms of text manipulation, such as but not limited to enlarging or shrinking of the message/text is prohibited. Scrolling text is prohibited. Static images, graphics, or pictures shall be displayed in the same color as the text elements of the electronic message. Color variations within the electronic message are prohibited. 
6.  Construction/installation standards. Monument electronic message signs are required to be installed within the structural body of the monument sign, and may not be an addition to an already existing sign as an attachment. Monument electronic message signs shall not project outward or upward from the main body of the sign and must be installed or erected within the body of a new or the outline of an existing monument sign structure. All electronic wiring to power the electronic sign shall be concealed within the body of the monument sign and shall not be visible on the exterior of the monument sign. 
7.  Temporary signage forfeiture. Any property or development that chooses to utilize an electronic message sign, monument, shall forfeit the allotment of all forms of temporary signage allowed in this chapter. Temporary signage is meant only to provide an additional sign form to businesses for advertising or communicating information to the public. With the use of an electronic message sign, monument, the property or development has the diverse messaging capability to change messages to the public, and therefore negates the necessity of temporary signs. Once an electronic message sign, monument is erected upon a property all forms of temporary signage allowed by this chapter shall be prohibited; exception shall be for the erection of real estate signs that may be erected to advertise the real estate listing of the property, which is a separate business relationship to the use. 
C.  Electronic message sign, non-monument detached. 
1.  Allocation. One (1) per property, as the solitary detached sign. An electronic message sign shall be only permitted in lieu of the property or business exchanging all of the allowed detached sign square footage for installation and use of an electronic message sign. Therefore, no square footage for any additional detached signage is allowed if an electronic message sign is erected; or if there is an existing electronic messaging sign then no additional detached sign square footage shall be allowed until such time as the electronic message sign is removed from the premises. This includes the multiple detached sign allowance, if the property qualifies for multiple detached signs, any existing or proposed electronic message signage shall constitute a forfeiture of the additional detached signs, allowing only the one (1) singular detached sign, until such time as the electronic message sign is removed. Electronic message sign are not allowed to be attached to buildings/structures. 
2.  Maximum size. Shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet per side. 
3.  Maximum height. Shall not exceed twenty (20) feet. 
4.  Form. Limited to not more than two (2) sides one (1) sign face per side. 
5.  Message standard. Electronic message signs must display all messages as a static or fixed message/image of the entire screen/message board area for each message/image displayed. Static or fixed messages/images must be displayed a minimum of ten (10) seconds before rotating or displaying the next message. Scrolling, blinking, or other form of moving text is prohibited. 
6.  Color form standard. Electronic message signs shall be limited to a black background, and a single uniform text and/or graphic color. All programmed messages the sign displays must be displayed utilizing the single selected text/graphic color being red, amber, white, blue, or green. All programmed messages the sign displays must be displayed utilizing the single selected text/graphic color. The selected message display color must be indicated at the time of permit application, and once selected and permitted, can only be altered by a permit application to amend the sign's permitted function to another color type. Flashing, blinking, or other forms of text manipulation, such as but not limited to enlarging or shrinking of the message/text is prohibited. Scrolling text is prohibited. Static images, graphics, or pictures shall be displayed in the same color as the text elements of the electronic message. Color variations within the electronic message are prohibited. 
7.  Construction/installation standards. 
a.  Maximum height. Electronic message signs shall be no more than twenty (20) feet high. 
b.  Setback requirements. Electronic message signs shall be subject to a twenty (20) foot setback from the property line; and thirty-five (35) feet from intersecting right-of way lines. 
c.  Design. 
i.  The supporting column(s) of an electronic message sign shall provide a solid masonry (stone, brick and/or stucco) base that matches the material of the adjacent building of five (5) feet in height from the ground or twenty-five (25) percent of the total sign height, whichever is greater. 
ii.  Any exposed support poles or columns shall be painted a flat black. 
iii.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. At minimum the address number must be displayed. If the sign is located near the corner of the property then the street name must be on the sign in addition to the address number. 
iv.  All electronic wiring to power the electronic sign shall be concealed within the body of the support poles for the sign and shall not be visible on the exterior of the support poles or sign. 
v.  Signs proposing an alternative designs utilizing other materials or colors may be approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
8.  Temporary signage forfeiture. Any property or development that choose to permit and utilize electronic message signs, shall forfeit the allotment of all forms of temporary signage allowed in this chapter. Temporary signage is meant only to provide an additional sign form to businesses for advertising or communicating information to the public. With the use of an electronic message sign the property or development has the diverse messaging capability to change messages to the public, and therefore negates the necessity of temporary signs. Once an electronic message sign is erected upon a property all forms of temporary signage allowed by this chapter shall be prohibited; exception shall be for the erection of real estate signs that may be erected to advertise the real estate listing of the property, which is a separate business relationship to the use and advertising of the premises. 
D.  Time and temperature sign. 
1.  Allocation. One (1) allowed per property. None allowed attached to buildings/structures. Time and temperature signs are not allowed to be erected in combination with electronic message signs, standard. 
2.  Maximum area. Shall not exceed twenty-four (24) square feet, per side. 
3.  Form. Limited to not more than two (2) sides one (1) sign face per side. 
4.  Messaging standard. Time and temperature text must be displayed as a static or fixed full-screen message for each message displayed. Time and temperature messages must be displayed a minimum of six (6) seconds before rotating or displaying the next message. Scrolling, blinking, or other form of moving text is prohibited. If at any time any content other than time and temperature messaging is displayed, then the sign shall be classified as an electronic message sign, thereby requiring the sign to comply with all standards applicable within this chapter to electronic messaging signs. 
5.  Color form standard. Time and temperature signs must have a black background, and a single uniform text color of red, white, or amber. Varying text colors of the messaging is prohibited. 
E.  Gas/fuel price electronic message sign. 
1.  Allocation. One (1) allowed per business or property. May be allowed to be attached to buildings/structures or on a detached sign. 
2.  Maximum size. Shall not exceed eighteen (18) total square feet per sign face; which may consist of individual pricing panels six (6) square feet per gas/fuel price panel, with a maximum of three (3) fuel/gas price(s) (Unleaded, Premium, Diesel) per detached sign and/or building/structure. In no instance shall an electronic message panel extend beyond the face of the canopy. 
3.  Form. Limited to not more than two (2) sides with one (1) sign face per side. For purposes of this requirement, the two (2) sign sides may be located on separate faces of a canopy over a fueling area. 
4.  Messaging standard. Gas/fuel numbers must be displayed as a static. Gas/fuel messages must be displayed a minimum of ten (10) seconds before rotating or displaying the next message. Scrolling, blinking, or other form of moving text is prohibited. The advertising of any goods, services, or prices for anything other than gas/fuel upon this sign is prohibited. If at any time any content other than gas/fuel messaging is displayed, then the sign will be classified as an electronic message sign, thereby requiring the sign to comply with all standards applicable within these regulations to electronic messaging signs. 
5.  Color form standard. Gas/fuel signs must have a black background, and a single uniform text color of red, white, green, or amber within each sign panel. Varying text colors within each sign panel of the messaging is prohibited. 
6.  Existing nonconforming signs. Existing nonconforming signs seeking to install electronic gas/fuel price message signs must show substantial improvements to existing sign in conformance with section 20-15 G. 
F.  Electronic message sign, site specific. 
1.  Allocation. One (1) allowed per property. None allowed attached to buildings/structure. 
2.  Maximum area. Shall not exceed eighteen (18) square feet. 
3.  Location. This sign form is not for advertising to the general public, but for the communication of information to users/visitors to a specific site. Therefore, these signs are encouraged not face the public right-of-way. The only exception to this standard would be electronic message signs communicating the pricing of gas or fuel pricing available on the site, with the condition that the price is the only information displayed on the sign and subject to the standards herein. 
4.  Messaging standard. Site specific electronic message signs must only display all messages as a static or fixed message/image of the entire screen/message board area for each message/image displayed. Static or fixed messages/images are not limited to a minimum timeframe of display. Scrolling, blinking, or other form of moving text is prohibited. 
5.  Color form standard. Site specific standard electronic messaging signs shall be limited to a black background, and a single uniform text and graphic color of red, white, or amber, except that prices for the separate fuel types may utilized the standard red and green. Varying text colors of the messaging is prohibited. Flashing of text is prohibited. Scrolling text is prohibited. Static images, graphic, or pictures shall be displayed in the same color as the text elements of the electronic message. Color variations within the electronic message are prohibited. 
G.  Searchlight or beacon sign. 
1.  Allocation. None. All searchlight or beacon sign types are prohibited in the city. 
2.  Special event provision. A special event sign permit may be obtained from the development services department for the use of a searchlight or beacon sign for a maximum of two (2) times per year, not to exceed five (5) days each time, for each special event. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2016-O-05A, § II, 5-3-2016 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , §§ II.E—II.I, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-9. - Attached signs. 
This section governs the regulation of all permanent forms of signage attached to a building or structure within the city and its ETJ. Except as otherwise authorized herein, no sign shall be erected, structurally changed or reconstructed in whole or part, within the city without a permit having been first obtained. 
A.  Permanent building signage. Signs, when attached to buildings shall advertise only services or products which are offered within the building to which the sign is attached. 
1.  Construction/installation standards. Such signs shall not extend above the roof line of such building for more than two (2) feet. Under no circumstances shall an attached sign be allowed to extend past the ends of a building or more than two (2) feet above the roof line of a building nor cover more than fifty (50) percent of the front or side of a building. Attached signs shall not extend more than fifteen (15) inches from the face of the building surface, unless it meets the requirements to be classified as a projected or awning signs, which the applicable regulations to those sign categories shall apply. 
a.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset, and address numbers shall be attached directly to the face of the sign. Reflective surfaces are not permitted. 
b.  Lighting. Internal or external lighting of attached signs is allowed. 
2.  Maximum size. The total area of all signs attached to the building shall not exceed one (1) square foot for each one (1) linear foot of building front. Buildings adjacent to a side street shall be allowed to include the linear footage of the side of the building adjacent to an improved side street when calculating the total allowable sign area. 
3.  Awning sign. 
a.  Maximum area/allocation. Awning signs shall be erected under the allotted square footage for total area attached to buildings as prescribed above. 
b.  Awning signs shall not be constructed of banners or non-rigid materials, unless it is constructed as a structural element of the awning itself, such as a business name stitched into or printed upon the material of the awning canopy. 
c.  Awning signs in the main street district. 
i.  An awning sign in the main street district shall not project more than two (2) feet from the awning it is affixed. 
ii.  An awning sign in the main street district can project over sidewalks and walkways in the public right-of-way. 
d.  Awning signs in all other districts. 
i.  An awning sign shall not project more than one (1) foot from the awning it is affixed. 
ii.  An awning sign shall not project over public right-of-way. 
4.  Neon sign. 
a.  Allocation. Neon signs are allowed but must be erected within the allotted attached signs attributed to a building. 
b.  Maximum area. Established by maximum attached sign square footage to building. 
c.  Display. Neon signs are prohibited from pulsing, flashing, or any other function that would create a moving sign. The display of neon signs is to provide a form of fixed illumination. 
d.  Location. Neon signs are prohibited from attachment to any form of detached signage. Neon signs shall be permitted to be attached to buildings within which a business operates. Neon signs are prohibited from attachment to accessory structures or detached structures from the primary business building. 
e.  An "open" neon sign within a window of a business or attached to the exterior of the business shall not be counted as sign square footage for a building allotment. An "open" sign shall be limited to four (4) square feet. 
5.  Projecting sign. No sign structure or sign support attached to a building shall project from the building more than two (2) feet, except for signs placed on a business in the main street district. Such projections must be a minimum of eight (8) feet above the walkway adjacent to the building for head clearance. Projecting signs shall not be supported by any structural support poles, but shall be an extension of the building façade. Projecting signs shall not extend farther than six (6) feet from the building face which it is attached. 
B.  Window signage. 
1.  Purpose. To maintain the functional use of windows in buildings as they are intended to be utilized and minimize the volume of signage within windows on structures. 
2.  Window signs are permitted. The total area of all window signs on any given elevation of a building may not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the window area of that elevation. 
3.  No single window sign shall exceed a fifty (50) percent cover of the area of the window. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-10. - Temporary signs. 
This section governs the regulation of all forms of temporary signage within the city and its ETJ. No sign may be erected, structurally changed, refaced, or reconstructed in whole or part, within the city without a permit having been first obtained. 
A.  Attached temporary signs. 
1.  Banner signs. 
a.  Purpose. To allow businesses and organizations the opportunity to advertise special events or functions, such as but not limited to: Opening soon, closing soon, business relocation, specials, sales, promotions, fundraisers, community events, etc. 
b.  Allocation. One (1) temporary banner sign per business limited to the following requirements: 
i.  One (1) temporary banner shall be permitted at a time. 
ii.  A single temporary banner sign may be permitted not more than four (4) times a year, for a maximum of forty-five (45) days for each instance. 
iii.  A minimum of thirty (30) days shall be required between permitting one (1) sign to the next, so the instance of a perpetual banner sign does not occur. 
iv.  A single temporary banner sign may be permitted as the interim permanent sign for a new business for up to sixty (60) days. Prior to the expiration of the sixty (60) day time period application for the permanent sign must be made. The city manager or designee may authorize an extension to the allotted sixty (60) days on a case-by-case basis. 
c.  Maximum size. Thirty-two (32) square feet. 
d.  Location requirements. Temporary banner signs shall only be affixed to buildings or structures. Any temporary banner signs must have a head clearance minimum of eight (8) feet, if they are overhanging pedestrian access routes or paths. Temporary banner signs are prohibited from utilization in residential zoning districts, such as NR, TR, DR, ENZ.2, ENZ.3, or other PDD district equivalents. 
e.  Setback requirements. None, temporary banner signs shall not be detached, and therefore shall only be attached to buildings. 
f.  Design. 
i.  Material for a temporary banner sign must be made of vinyl or an equally weather resistant material. 
ii.  All letters and numbers must be typeset. 
g.  Lighting. The lighting of temporary banner signs is prohibited. 
B.  Detached temporary signs. 
1.  Purpose. To allow businesses and organizations the opportunity to advertise special events or functions, including but not limited to: opening soon, closing soon, business relocation, specials, sales, promotions, fundraisers, community events, etc. 
2.  General regulations. All temporary detached signs shall comply with the following regulations, unless specified herein. 
a.  A permit is required for all temporary detached sign types. 
b.  Only one (1) type of detached temporary sign may be permitted at one (1) time. Combinations of these sign types are prohibited, except that a business conducting a grand opening or business relocation may combine two (2) of these temporary sign types for a sixty (60) day period. 
c.  A permit required under this section must be approved no less than thirty (30) days prior to the installation of signs described by subsections B.2, 3., and 4., except that businesses conducting grand openings, relocations or closings and that have had a temporary sign permitted within the last thirty (30) days need not apply for an additional permit. 
3.  Temporary sandwich board signs. 
a.  Maximum size. Twenty-four (24) square feet; shall not be wider than four (4) feet. 
b.  Maximum height. Six (6) feet. 
c.  Allocation. Each business shall be allowed to a sandwich board signs subject to one (1) of the following methods: 
i.  Two (2) sandwich board signs shall be permitted up to four (4) times a year, for a maximum of thirty (30) days for each instance. If only one (1) sandwich board sign is permitted, the maximum length of time for display extends to forty-five (45) days for each instance. A minimum of thirty (30) days shall pass between the permitting of one (1) sign to the next, except that signs permitted for grand openings, business relocations, or closing events may be permitted for up to sixty (60) days, or; 
ii.  Sandwich board signs may utilize a portion of the thirty (30) days allowed by erecting the sandwich board signs on the weekends only. Each weekend the sandwich board signs are erected shall count as two (2) days deducting from remainder of the original thirty (30) days permitted. Once the thirty (30) days is utilized a new permit for a new thirty (30) day time period must be obtained. Signs on the weekend only time period is the following timeframe, after 5:00 p.m. Fridays and removed by 8:00 a.m. Monday morning. Failure to comply with the weekend only time period may result in the permit being revoked and the loss of temporary sign permit privileges for a period of up to six (6) months. The business shall keep an accounting of when the sign is erected and when it is not. 
iii.  One (1) sandwich board sign may be permitted for a reoccurring weekly event for a single day of the week. The day of the week must be specified upon permitting and may be continued for the duration of the permit. The sign may only be posted and displayed on the single permitted day of the week. Failure to comply with this single-day rule may result in the permit being revoked and the loss of temporary sign permit privileges for a period of up to six (6) months. An annual permit for a reoccurring weekly event temporary sign is required. 
d.  Location requirements. Sandwich board signs shall be located on the premises of the business, organization, or even for which they advertise. Sandwich board signs shall not create a traffic circulation disturbance or a vision obstruction. Sandwich board signs shall not block pedestrian paths, entrances or exits to buildings. Sandwich board signs are prohibited from utilization in residential zoning districts, such as NR, TR, DR, MR, ENZ.2, ENZ.3, ENZ.4, or other PDD district equivalents. 
e.  Design. 
i.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset. 
ii.  Lighting. Internal or external lighting of sandwich board signs is prohibited. 
f.  Removal/storage. The sandwich board signs must be removed and stored daily, upon close of business. 
g.  Maintenance. Sandwich board signs must be maintained in good condition. Visible damage or wear and tear is not permitted. Sandwich board signs shall remain upright on the property and shall be returned to an upright position immediately if the sign falls or is blown over. Signs must be removed and stored indoors during periods of hazardous weather. 
4.  Feather flag signs (tear drop banners). 
a.  Maximum size. Sixteen (16) feet maximum height and three (3) feet wide. 
b.  Allocation. Feather flag signs shall not be used as a permanent sign for a business/development. Each business shall be allowed feather flag signs as follows: 
i.  Two (2) feather flag signs may be permitted for a property for six (6) months for each instance. However, individual businesses within a multi-tenant shopping center may be permitted one (1) feather flag for six (6) months for each instance. 
ii.  A minimum of thirty (30) days shall pass between the permitting of one (1) sign to the next. 
c.  Location requirements. Feather flag signs shall be located within the premises of the business, organization, or event for which they advertise. Feather flag signs shall not create a traffic circulation disturbance or a vision obstruction to neighboring signs or traffic accessibility. Feather flag signs shall not block pedestrian paths, entrances or exits to buildings. Feather flag signs are prohibited from utilization in residential zoning districts, such as NR, TR, DR, ENZ.2, ENZ.3, or other PDD district equivalents. 
d.  Setback requirements. None. Feather flag signs may be placed on the property line provided all other provisions of this section are met. 
e.  Design. 
i.  Material for a feather flag sign must be made of vinyl or an equally weather resistant material. Paper, cardboard, similar material or non-weather resistant material is prohibited. 
ii.  All letters and numbers must be typeset. 
f.  Lighting. The lighting of feather flag signs is prohibited. 
g.  Maintenance. Feather flag signs must be maintained in good condition with no tears, frayed edges, or discoloration. Visible damage, wear and tear, or weathering is prohibited and will result in the sign permit being revoked or denied. Feather flag signs shall remain upright on the property and shall be returned to an upright position immediately if the sign falls or is blown over. Signs must be removed and stored indoors during periods of hazardous weather. 
5.  Plastic stake signs. 
a.  Maximum size. Six (6) square feet per plastic stake sign. 
b.  Maximum height. Three (3) feet. 
c.  Allocation. Each business shall be allowed plastic stake signs per business subject to one (1) of the following methods: 
i.  Four (4) plastic stake signs shall be permitted up to four (4) times a year, for a maximum of fifteen (15) days for each instance. A minimum of thirty (30) days shall be required between permitting one (1) sign to the next, so the instance of a perpetual temporary sign does not occur. 
ii.  The combination or simultaneous permitting of these signs at the same time as feather flags or plastic stake signs is prohibited. Only one (1) type of detached temporary sign type is allowed to be permitted at a time. 
d.  Location requirements. Plastic stake signs shall be located within the property they advertise. Plastic stake signs shall not create a traffic circulation disturbance or a vision obstruction. Plastic stake signs shall not block pedestrian paths, entrances or exits to buildings. Plastic stake signs are prohibited from utilization in residential zoning districts, such as NR, TR, DR, MR, ENZ.2, ENZ.3, ENZ.4, or other PDD district equivalents. 
e.  Setback requirements. None. Plastic stake signs may be placed on the property line provided all other provisions of this section are met. 
f.  Design. 
i.  Material for a plastic stake sign must be made of corrugated plastic, polystyrene, metal, or an equally weather resistant material. 
ii.  All letters and numbers must be typeset. 
g.  Lighting. The lighting of plastic stake signs is prohibited. 
h.  Maintenance. Plastic stake signs must be maintained in good condition. Visible damage or wear and tear is prohibited. Plastic stake signs shall remain upright on the property and shall be returned to an upright position immediately if the sign falls or is blown over. Signs must be removed and stored indoors during periods of hazardous weather. 
6.  Sandwich board signs (main street district only). 
a.  Purpose. To provide a viable detached sign alternative to businesses in the downtown district for visibility of pedestrians. The Marble Falls Downtown Master Plan encourages the use of temporary signs within the district. This section provides regulations for the use of temporary signs within that district. 
b.  Maximum size. Ten (10) square feet; shall not be wider than three (3) feet. 
c.  Maximum height. Four (4) feet. 
d.  Allocation. Each ground-floor store front shall be allowed to display one (1) sandwich board sign. 
e.  Location. 
i.  The sandwich board may be used on the sidewalk immediately adjacent to the business it represents, in an area defined by the edge of sidewalk pavement and two (2) perpendicular lines found by an imaginary extension of the building space lines or lot lines to this curb. Any other locations of sandwich board signs are considered off-premise signage and prohibited by this chapter. Sandwich board signs may not be placed in the street. 
ii.  Sandwich signs must be placed so as not to interfere with the movement of pedestrians upon the sidewalk. The sandwich sign must be placed within two (2) feet of the building face or within one (1) foot of the curb line on the outer edge of the sidewalk or within the landscape area on the outer edge of the sidewalk, if one exists. Sandwich signs may be placed in landscape areas on private property for buildings/sites with conventional setbacks in the main street district. 
iii.  Sandwich signs are not allowed to be placed in the street, parking stalls, or any area that is not sidewalk fronting the business as described in b. above. 
f.  Design. 
i.  All letters and numbers shall be typeset; unless a chalk menu board is used which the message must change daily. 
ii.  Lighting. Internal or external lighting of sandwich board signs is prohibited. 
g.  An annual permit is required for sandwich board signs. 
h.  Removal/storage. The sandwich board must be removed and stored upon close of business daily. 
7.  Balloons or other filled objects. 
a.  Balloons or other gas filled objects may be authorized for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days for business openings and fourteen (14) days for special occasions. A minimum of thirty (30) days shall be required between permitting one (1) sign to the next, so the instance of a perpetual temporary sign does not occur. A written permit shall be obtained from the city. No fee is required. 
b.  The object must be secured to the ground in a location so as to not create a traffic circulation disturbance or a vision obstruction to neighboring signs or traffic accessibility. The object shall not block pedestrian paths, entrances or exits to buildings. 
C.  Community or public service signs shall be limited to commercial and industrial districts and a drawing of all public service signs may be approved by city manager or designee. These signs do require a permit, but there shall be no fee. 
1.  Maximum size. Thirty-two (32) square feet. 
2.  Maximum of sixty (60) days per sign utilized. 
D.  Signage associated with a special or temporary event or concession with the city may be approved in conjunction with approval of the special or temporary event or the concession agreement and if approved in conjunction therewith, a separate sign permit is not required. Signage associated with a temporary or special event normally approved by the city council shall be approved by the council. Signage associated with a temporary or special event normally approved by city staff may be approved by city staff. 
E.  Development signs. Signs announcing or describing a legally approved subdivision or land development may be temporarily erected until the subdivision is completed. Such signs shall not exceed one hundred (100) square feet in area and may be indirectly lighted. An annual permit is required. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-01B , § II.D, 1-15-2019; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , §§ II.C, II.J—II.M, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-11. - Miscellaneous sign form requirements. 
This section governs the regulation of all permanent forms of other signage within the city and its ETJ. No sign may be erected, structurally changed or reconstructed in whole or part, within the city and its ETJ without having obtained a permit from the city. 
A.  Subdivision sign. A permanent sign erected at the entrance of a subdivision or development. These signs are allowed to only provide geographic information by providing the name of the subdivision or development to the general public. Subdivision signs shall be limited in size to the monument sign regulations as provided above. 
B.  Mobile home park. A monument sign or retaining wall sign of not more than sixty (60) square feet in total area may be erected on property of the mobile home park and may be indirectly lighted. A permit is required. 
C.  Construction traffic signage. Construction traffic signage may be erected only on a temporary, as needed basis and only in conjunction with an approved associated construction project. Such signage shall be limited in content to provide for the safe and efficient circulation of traffic in and around construction sites and associated detours. The city manager or designee shall approve the size, locations, and type of these signs. Construction traffic signage shall be composed of retro-reflective "construction orange" background with black text. 
D.  Wind load pressure requirements. No sign shall be erected that does not meet the wind load pressure requirements as set out in the table which follows this paragraph or as determined by the current adopted building code. Permit applications for new signs and permit renewals required for signs which will have or have a height, in feet above ground, as measured above the average level of the ground adjacent to the proposed structure, of six (6) feet, or more, must be accompanied by a certificate signed by design professional or licensed engineer to the effect that the proposed or existing sign will withstand wind load pressures in pounds per square foot as set out in the following table. Solely at the discretion of the building official, further verification may be required to prove that the wind loading specifications will be met. 
Wind Load Pressure in Pounds Per Square Foot 
Height, in feet above ground as measured above the average level of the ground adjacent to the structure. 
Pressure 	Pounds per Square Foot 
0—5 	0 
6—30 	20 
31—50 	25 
 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , § II.N, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-12. - Prohibited signs.
