Any sign not expressly authorized by this chapter, or specifically exempted from the provisions hereof, or considered a legal nonconforming sign pursuant to the provisions of this chapter is prohibited within the corporate limits of the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction. Prohibited signs include but are not limited to: 
A.  Signs and supports (other than those placed by the governmental authority such as street name signs) which are located within any public right-of-way. This section shall not apply to signs on commercial vehicles or commercial trailers lawfully operated or parked in such areas, except that this exception shall not otherwise be used to legitimize the use of advertising vehicles and trailers prohibited herein. 
B.  Sandwich or "A" frame signs, sidewalk or curb signs; unless specifically authorized herein. 
C.  Display of merchandise or examples of work are classified as signs, if any reference, thereon, is made to the business itself. In residential districts, no display of works or merchandise may be displayed, except for permitted garage sales. 
D.  All flags are prohibited except those of any nation, state, political subdivision. One (1) flag that shows an emblem or logo of a firm or corporation shall be permitted providing all other regulations are met. 
E.  Any signs which resemble an official traffic-control device or sign, or which bear the words of traffic-control. 
F.  Signs, which by reason of their size, location, movement, content, coloring or manner of illumination, may be confused with or construed as a traffic-control sign, signal or device or the light of an emergency or road equipment vehicle or which hides from view any traffic or street sign or any signal device. 
G.  Any sign which emits sound, odor or visible matter which serve as a distraction to persons who are within the public right-of-way. 
H.  Portable, wheeled, banner, and/or temporary signs are not allowed, unless specifically authorized herein. 
I.  Off-premise signs are prohibited. No signs shall be erected advertising products or services not available on the site. This provision also includes messages displayed on electronic signs. Electronic signage shall not display advertisement or messages for goods or services not available on the site. 
J.  Signs may not be constructed of scrap materials, paper or other fragile materials, which are not weather-resistant. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-13. - Landmark signs. 
The city appreciates and recognizes potential for historical or iconic signs that contribute to the positive nature of the community. Therefore, the landmark sign procedure exists to allow application and consideration of permitting for these signs. Any sign permitted as a landmark sign may be exempt from the general regulations applicable to signs; except for applicable safety requirements and regulations that are referenced as being applicable to landmark signs. In order to designate a sign as a landmark type sign, the applicant shall submit an application according to the procedures set out in section 20-5 and this section. 
A.  Landmark sign must meet all of the following criteria: 
1.  Materials, technology, and design. Representative of excellence in a particular period of construction; and/or is unique in that it demonstrates extraordinary aesthetic quality, creativity or innovation. 
2.  Integrity. Retains the majority of its character-defining features (materials, technologies, structure, colors, shapes, symbols, text, and/or art) that have historical significance, or are integral to overall sign design, or convey historical or regional context. If character-defining features have been altered or removed, the majority are potentially restorable to their historic function and appearance. 
3.  Safety. Structurally safe or can be made safe without substantially altering its historical appearance. 
4.  Location. The sign is not an off-site sign or billboard, unless approved in accordance with subsection E. 
B.  A historic sign must be constructed more than fifty (50) years before the date of application and must meet all of the criteria for landmark sign designation and must meet all of the following criteria: 
1.  A historic sign may be repaired, restored, and/or adaptively reused if there is sufficient surviving fabric or sufficient historical documentation (photographs, postcards, permits, or other records) on which to base the treatment concept. An existing historic sign may be repaired, restored, or rehabilitated either in place, or off-site and then re-erected on site. 
2.  A historic sign may be repaired or restored to any past appearance prior to fifty (50) years before the date of application. If the owner of an historic sign can provide documentation or physical evidence that the original design included intermittent lighting features (e.g., flashing, blinking, chasing or sequentially lit elements which create the appearance of movement) or moving parts, those sign elements may be repaired and restored. 
3.  A historic sign that will be adaptively reused must retain, repair, or restore the majority of the character-defining features (e.g., materials, technologies, structure, colors, shapes, symbols, text, typography and/or artwork) that have historical significance, or are integral to the overall design of the sign, or convey historical or regional context. Changes to character-defining text are not allowed; any or all text that is not character defining can be changed. Changes to text must either match or be compatible with existing text or the text being replaced, in terms of materials, letter size, font, and color. 
C.  A vintage sign must meet all of the criteria for landmark sign designation and must meet all of the following criteria: 
1.  Age. Constructed between fifty (50) and twenty-five (25) years before the date of application. 
2.  Applications for signs constructed within twenty-five (25) years of the date of application may be considered on the cultural and iconic contribution to the surroundings. 
D.  Replica sign. 
1.  A replica sign is permissible when based on sufficient historical documentation of the sign and its location. A replica sign must use historical materials and technologies, or use contemporary materials and technologies that visually match historical ones. 
E.  Guidelines for relocating a landmark sign. 
1.  Provided that the landmark sign complies with subsections E.2.—4., landmark sign may be relocated as follows: 
a.  To another location on the premises; 
b.  To another location that houses the same or similar business; 
c.  To an areas of similar character within a one (1) mile radius of the present location; or 
d.  To the original location. 
2.  A designated landmark sign shall not be relocated to residentially zoned property. 
3.  A designated landmark signs shall not be relocated within one hundred and fifty (150) feet of a primary structure on a residentially zoned property. 
4.  All relocations are subject to the following: 
a.  Detached signs must be located no less than ten (10) feet from the face of the curb or edge of pavement. Where there is no curb, the measurement shall be taken from the street property line. 
b.  Projecting signs that project into the public right-of-way shall follow the rules and procedures of this chapter, and shall follow the sign permitting process. 
F.  Sign calculations for a landmark sign. 
1.  Where the landmark sign does not identify the business occupying the premises, and is not used by an owner or occupant of the premises to advertise a business currently occupying the premises, the landmark sign shall not count against the total allowable sign area for the premises and shall not count against the number of signs allowed for the premises. 
2.  Where the landmark sign does identify the business occupying the premises or is used or adaptively reused by an owner or occupant of the premises to advertise a business currently occupying the premises, fifty (50) percent of the square footage of the landmark sign shall count toward the total allowable sign area and shall count against the number of signs allowed for the premises. 
3.  One hundred (100) percent of the square footage of a replica sign shall count toward the total allowable sign area for the premises and shall count against the number of signs allowed for the premises. 
G.  Administration and procedures. 
1.  Final approval by the planning and zoning commission. Planning and zoning commission approval shall be required for a landmark sign designation. A landmark permit will be issued as evidence of the designation. The denial of a landmark sign designation by the planning and zoning commission shall be final, unless the applicant files a written appeal to the city council within ten (10) days from the date of the denial. 
H.  Expiration of approval. 
1.  If the approved site plan for landmark sign designation has not been permitted within six (6) months after designation is granted, the designation shall be removed. If the permit lapses and the landmark sign has not been constructed then the designation shall be removed. The applicant may reapply for designation. 
2.  If a landmark permit is issued for a landmark sign in existence on the date of enactment of this chapter, the permit will be valid for the life of the sign so long as the sign maintains compliance with requirement of this section. 
3.  If a landmark sign permit is issued to authorize the repair, replacement or relocation of a landmark sign, the authorization to repair, replace or relocate the landmark sign shall be valid for one hundred and eighty (180) days from the date of issuance. If the landmark sign is not repaired, replaced or relocated as provided by the landmark permit prior to the expiration of one hundred and eighty (180) days, the permit will automatically expire and the signage will lose its landmark designation. Provided however, that an applicant may request an extension of the deadline for an additional ninety (90) day period if the request is submitted to the city manager or designee prior to the expiration of the initial one hundred and eighty (180) day period. 
4.  If a landmark sign ceases to comply with the requirements of subsection B., or is altered in a way that is not consistent with the criteria applicable to landmark signs, the city will notify the landowner that the sign no longer complies with the requirements that entitle it to landmark designation and the landowner shall have thirty (30) days to repair or correct the deficiencies. If the landowner fails to correct the deficiencies, the landmark permit shall expire and the signage will be subject to the regulations applicable to other signs. If the landowner disagrees with the city's determination, it may appeal the decision to the planning and zoning commission so long as the appeal is submitted prior to the expiration of the thirty (30) day period. The decision may be appealed from the commission to the city council with the appeal is submitted within ten (10) days of the date of the commission decision. The landmark permit will not expire during the pendency of any appeal and for an additional ten (10) days after the date of the commission's decision, or of the council's decision if an appeal is submitted to the council. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-14. - Fees. 
A sign permit shall be obtained prior to the erection of any sign not exempted herein. Permit fees are established as set out in the Master Fee Schedule, Appendix C. A separate electrical permit is required to be obtained, by a licensed electrician for signs requiring electrical components to be constructed. Any sign(s) erected or refaced without having first obtained a permit shall be subject to a fee of twice (two (2) times) the base permit fee amount to obtain a sign permit. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , § II.O, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-15. - Nonconforming signs. 
A.  Nonconforming signs are subject to the following requirements: 
1.  On-premise signs. Any nonconforming on-premise sign or sign structure that advertises or identifies a business, structure, person or activity which ceases to operate shall remove the name of the person, business or activity within thirty (30) days of the date that the business, person or activity ceased. This requirement does not apply to the sign structure. The sign structure shall not be structurally changed or reconstructed in whole or part, except for maintenance operations or for changing the letters, symbols or message without bringing the sign into full compliance with this chapter. Provided however, that a nonconforming sign may be repaired or rebuilt and returned to its original nonconforming state if the sign is damaged by fire or other cause (other than intentional act of owner) and the cost to repair the sign is not more than forty (40) percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type at the same location. 
2.  Any nonconforming on-premise sign and sign structure that advertises or identifies a business, structure, person or activity which ceases to operate shall remove the sign and sign structure on or before the expiration of one (1) year from the date that the business, person or activity ceased, unless brought into compliance. If the sign or sign structure is located on premises that were occupied by one (1) or more tenants, then the sign and sign structure must be removed on or before the expiration of two (2) years from the date that the business, structure, person or activity ceased to operate, unless brought into compliance. 
3.  Off-premise signs. Any nonconforming off-premise sign shall be removed if at any time the sign or a substantial part of it is blown down, destroyed or dismantled for any purpose other than maintenance operations or for changing the letters, symbols, or other matter on the sign. The sign or a substantial part of it is considered destroyed if the cost of repairing the sign is more than sixty (60) percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type at the same location. 
B.  In the event that a non-conforming sign loses its nonconforming status as described in subsection A. and is not removed by the owner, the city shall order the owner of the property on which the sign is located to remove the sign or, if the owner fails to do so, the city may remove the sign and file a lien on the property where the sign is located for the city's costs of such removal. Thereafter, no new signs shall be erected except pursuant to requirements of this chapter. 
C.  When nonconforming signs have been damaged by fire or other causes, but less than the applicable amounts that would cause them to lose their nonconforming status the city may issue a "no fee" permit for the necessary repairs to be made to the sign. If the necessary repairs are not completed within sixty (60) days of the date of issuance of the permit, then the sign shall be removed either by the owner or by the city at the owner's expense. 
D.  Signs so removed under the provisions of this section may be kept in storage (but the city is under no duty to do so) for a period of sixty (60) days and if they are not claimed within said period, they may be disposed of by the city. 
E.  Nonconforming electronic message signs existing at the time of adoption of this chapter utilizing multi-colored displays with colors or color schemes not in compliance with applicable color form standards contained herein shall not be required to bring such colors or color schemes into compliance so long as the message display meets all other requirements for electronic message signs, such as timing of messages, absence of flashing lights and similar provisions. 
F.  Existing signs and billboards outside the city limit and ETJ at the time of adoption of these regulation and that are later taken into the city limits or ETJ, shall be treated as nonconforming signs in accordance with this section. 
G.  Non-conforming on premise signs exception. Non-conforming on premise signs may be authorized to make substantial improvements to a sign without bringing the sign into full compliance with the city's sign regulations upon issuance of a limited permit as follows: 
1.  Limited permit. The applicant must demonstrate that substantial improvements to the sign will be undertaken. 
2.  The issuance of a limited permit is discretionary with the city. 
3.  An applicant for a limited permit shall follow the application process described in section 20-5 and submit the information required for regular sign permits. The process for approval of a limited permit will follow the process applicable to issuance of a regular sign permit. 
4.  The issuance of a limited permit shall authorize the permittee to repair and replace the sign in the event that the sign is damaged or destroyed so long as the limited permit has not expired. 
5.  A limited permit shall expire ten (10) years from the date of issuance. 
6.  A limited permit shall expire within sixty (60) days of the date of issuance if the substantial improvements to the sign are not commenced and diligently pursued to completion. 
7.  The substantial improvements to a sign under this section shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  Be performed only one (1) time and shall not: 
i.  Increase the degree of existing nonconformity; 
ii.  Increase the illumination of the sign; and 
iii.  Shall not be authorized within any of the following residential zoning districts, such as NR, TR, DR, MR, ENZ.2, ENZ.3, ENZ.4, or other PDD district equivalents. 
b.  A limited permit may be issued to authorize modification or replacement of the sign in the same location, if the modification or replacement reduces: 
i.  The sign area by twenty (20) percent; 
ii.  The height of the sign by at least twenty (20) percent; 
iii.  Relocation of the sign to a minimum ten (10) foot setback; or 
iv.  Both sign area and height of the sign by an amount which, combined, is equal to at least twenty (20) percent of the sign area and height. 
c.  Masonry (brick, stone, or stucco) may be applied to the sign, consistent with sections 20-6.B.7.a., 20-6.C.7.a., 20-6.D.9.a., and 20-6.G.7.a. or an equivalent aesthetic upgrade of alternative design utilizing other materials may be approved by the city manager or designee. An applicant may appeal the decision of the city manager to the planning and zoning commission. 
d.  The building, project, or facility address must be displayed on any sign fronting the street from which the address is derived. Address numbers and letters shall be a minimum of eight (8) inches in height. If the sign is located near an intersection, the address number must include the street name as part of the address displayed. In order to prevent confusion and the delay of emergency services, the address shall be displayed so as to face only the street on which the building represented by the sign fronts. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-01B , § II.D, 1-15-2019; Ord. No. 2019-O-02A , § II.P, 2-19-2019)  
Sec. 20-16. - Variance procedure. 
There is a variance request procedure (for requests to deviate from these regulations) established by this chapter. No variance shall be allowed for any sign that is prohibited under these regulations or for any non-conforming prohibited sign type that is required to be removed pursuant to these regulations. 
A.  In order to lessen practical difficulties and prevent unnecessary physical hardships, variances from these regulations may be granted. A practical difficulty or unnecessary physical hardship may result from the size, shape, or dimensions of a structure, or the location of the structure, from topographic or physical limitations, locations, or traffic conditions in the immediate vicinity. Cost or inconvenience to the applicant of strict or literal compliance with this chapter is not a reason for granting a variance. 
B.  Except for prohibited signs, a variance may be granted with respect to any regulation contained in this chapter in accordance with the procedures set forth herein. 
C.  The planning and zoning commission may approve, deny or approve with conditions variances to these regulations. The commission may approve a variance with conditions such as reduced size, color alterations or similar conditions to protect the public health, safety and welfare and ensure compatibility with the harmony and character of the city. 
D.  A decision by the planning and zoning commission may be appealed to the city council, if the appeal is filed within ten (10) days of the date of the commission's decision. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-17. - Penalties for violation. 
The penalties established in section 1-9 shall apply to sign regulation violations. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Sec. 20-18. - City's authority to remove illegal signs. 
An illegal sign is any sign that is erected or placed in violation of this chapter and which is not classified as a nonconforming sign. The city may remove any illegal sign after having provided written notice to the owner five (5) days before said sign is removed. Upon removal of any sign pursuant to this section, the city shall use reasonable care to preserve such sign. The city shall not be liable for any damages, direct, indirect or consequential caused by the removal. The city may dispose of any illegal sign if not claimed by the owner within ten (10) days of the date of removal. If the sign does not contain sufficient information to ascertain the name and address of the owner of the sign, no notification prior to removal shall be necessary. If the owner does not reclaim the sign within ten (10) days of the date of removal, the city may dispose of the sign. 
( Ord. No. 2013-O-09C, § II.B, 10-1-2013 )  
Chapter 21 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisances, Ch. 13; littering in city parks, § 15-19; littering in Lake Marble Falls, § 15-47; utilities, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Accumulation and removal of garbage and refuse, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477—1, § 4; Solid Waste Disposal Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477—7; Texas Litter Abatement Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477—9a. 
 
Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Alley means any public way, generally of less width than a street, used for public utility purposes and right-of-way and an alternate secondary or emergency route for vehicle and pedestrian traffic, generally situated at the rear of or alongside a tier of lots. 
Bags means plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed thirty-five (35) pounds. 
Bin means a plastic 300-gallon capacity receptacle designed to be lifted and emptied mechanically; to be primarily used to service commercial businesses. 
Brush means tree cuttings, twigs, branches, leaves, shrubbery, grass clippings and organic material resulting from yard maintenance. 
Bulky waste means items that will not normally fit inside the 96-gallon cart including furniture, mattresses, appliances with coolant removed, rugs, carpet, carpet padding, bundled brush and yard waste and similar items. Bulky waste does not include demolition or construction debris, stumps, tree trunks or limbs exceeding two (2) inches in diameter or three (3) feet in length. 
Bundle means tree, shrub and brush trimmings or newspapers and magazines securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding three (3) feet in length or thirty-five (35) pounds in weight. Also, bundled newspaper, magazines and other recyclable paper which may not exceed twenty (20) pounds per bundle and tied with string or rope. 
Cart means a 96-gallon capacity, wheeled, lidded cart for the storage and automated collection of solid wastes from residences and small businesses. 
Commercial establishment means any structure intended or used for the purpose of conducting a commercial business enterprise. 
Commercial, industrial and institutional refuse means all garbage, rubbish, solid waste, and waste material generated by a business; industry, factory, mall, school, hospital, health care facility, sports facility or complex, excluding excluded waste. 
Construction and demolition (C&D) debris means debris that is produced during new construction, renovation, remodeling, and demolition of buildings and structures. C&D debris includes but is not limited to bricks, concrete, masonry, lumber, paving materials, shingles, glass, plastics, aluminum (including siding), steel, drywall, insulation, asphalt roofing materials, electrical materials, plumbing fixtures, vinyl siding, and corrugated cardboard or packing material for construction materials. 
Container refers to any cart, bin, dumpster or roll-off container; whether for residential, commercial, industrial, municipal or other application. 
Container for recycling (recycling bin) means a plastic 18-gallon capacity bin provided to all residences to store and provide collection of recyclable materials. 
Demolition means the reconstruction, remodeling, or destruction of sixty (60) percent or more of a structure or building. 
Excluded waste means all hazardous waste, hazardous industrial waste, medical waste and large dead animals (as those terms are defined herein). Included in this definition of excluded waste is any waste prohibited from disposal in an MSW facility by 30 TAC 330.15(e). 
Food establishment means cafe, restaurant or other similar establishment serving food or food products, including quick-service drive-ins where food is prepared or served. 
Garbage means any and all small dead animals; every accumulation of waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the preparation, processing, consumption, dealing in, handling, packing, canning, storage, transportation, decay or decomposition of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not by way of limitation, used tin cans and other food containers; and all putrescible or easily decomposable waste animal or vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies or rodents); except (in all cases) any matter included in the definition of excluded waste. 
Handicap residential unit means a dwelling where one (1) or more persons reside who, because of temporary or permanent physical conditions, are unable to transport refuse from their residence to the curb for pickup. 
Hazardous waste means a form of excluded waste and is defined as any radioactive, volatile, corrosive, highly flammable, explosive, biomedical, infectious, biohazardous, toxic or listed or characteristic hazardous waste as defined by federal, state, provincial or local law or any otherwise regulated waste. Hazardous waste shall include, but not be limited to, any amount of waste listed or characterized as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or any state agency pursuant to the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, as amended, and including future amendments thereto, and any other applicable federal, state or local laws or regulations. 
Health officer means the head of the county health department or anyone authorized to act for him. 
Illegally dumped rubbish or trash means any rubbish or trash placed on properties with or without the consent of the owner or person in control where such waste constitutes a nuisance detrimental to the public health and welfare. 
Industrial solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to a process of industry or manufacturing, or mining or agricultural operations. 
Large dead animals means animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than ten (10) pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use. 
Licensee means an individual or entity licensed under section 21-16 to participate in waste collection services for temporary C&D waste. 
Manager means the person in charge of real estate used for apartment, institutional or commercial purposes. 
Medical waste means animal waste, bulk blood and blood products, microbiological waste, pathological waste, sharps, and special waste from health care-related facilities as those terms are defined in 25 TAC Section 1.132 (Texas Department of Health, Definition, Treatment, and Disposition of Special Waste from Health Care-Related Facilities). The term does not include medical waste produced on farmland and ranchland as defined in section 252.001(6), Agriculture Code. The term does not include artificial, nonhuman materials removed from a patient and requested by the patient, including, but not limited to, orthopedic devices and breast implants. 
Multifamily means all residential dwelling units of more than two (2) units considered to be condominiums, apartment houses or grouped housing. 
Municipal solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to municipal, community, trade, business and recreational activities, including garbage, rubbish (or trash), ashes, street cleanings, dead animals and all other solid waste other than excluded waste. 
Occupant means the person residing in a dwelling unit, specifically the head of such household. 
Owner means the record title holder of real property. 
Parkway means the area ordinarily intervening between the curb line of a street and the inside property line. 
Permittee means any person licensed by franchise agreement with the city to contract to collect, remove or dispose of solid waste. 
Producer means an operator or occupant (or a contractor providing services at) of a commercial business, industrial facility, multifamily unit or a residential unit who generates solid waste, special waste, garbage, rubbish, yard waste or recyclable materials. 
Property line means a peripheral boundary of real estate. 
Public utility easement means a right-of-way used or dedicated to be used by any public utility, including, but not limited to, services such as electricity, telephone, gas, water, sewer and drainage. 
Public way means any street, alley, easement or other right-of-way. 
Recyclables are materials that have a known reuse potential and established and available end-use markets and include paper, corrugated cardboard, plastic bottles and jugs, aluminum cans, steel and bi-metal cans and metal that are normally and commonly produced at residences, businesses, industries, institutions, schools and community activities. 
Recycling means an activity where waste materials are collected and diverted from disposal and directed toward reuse or processed for delivery to an end-use market where they are converted into new products. Long-term storage or dumping of materials on the land or in excavation pits is not recycling. 
Residential unit means a dwelling within the corporate limits of the city occupied by a person or group of persons comprising not more than two (2) families. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. A condominium dwelling, whether of single or multi-level construction, consisting of two (2) or less contiguous or separate single-family dwelling units, shall be treated as a residential unit, except that each single-family dwelling within any such residential unit shall be billed separately as a residential unit. 
Roll-off container means a container that is carried to a construction, remodeling or demolition site on a transport vehicle carriage and placed on the ground separate from the transport carriage. A roll-off container does not have rubber tires or rubber wheels. 
Rubbish means all waste wood, wood chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, used and discarded mattresses, used and discarded clothing, used and discarded shoes and boots, combustible waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging, or wrapping crockery and glass, ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not included in the definition of excluded waste. 
Sanitary landfill means a method of disposing of municipal solid waste on land without creating a nuisance or hazard to public health or safety by utilizing the principles of engineering to confine the solid waste to the smallest practical area, to reduce it to the smallest practical volume and to cover it with a layer of earth at appropriate periodic intervals. 
Small dead animals means animals or portions thereof less than ten (10) pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use. 
Solid waste means useless, unwanted or discarded materials with insufficient liquid content to be freeflowing that result from domestic, industrial, commercial, agricultural, governmental and community operations which require proper storage, collection, transportation and disposal to prevent environmental pollution inimical to public health, safety and welfare. Solid waste does not include sewage, earth or material used to fill land in accordance with construction codes, mining residues, slag, dissolved or suspended solids in industrial waste water effluents which are not acceptable for disposal in sanitary sewage treatment system or any material included in the definition of excluded waste. 
Special waste means nonhazardous solid waste that is subject to additional governmental regulations or special handling requirements in collection, transportation, processing or disposal as a result of the characteristics of, or processes that generate such waste. Special waste includes, but is not limited to, asbestos, or any waste defined as special by Texas Administrative Code 30 and as further defined in sections 330.3(148), 330.171, 330.173 or any adjunct regulations. Waste may be classified as special because of its quantity, concentration, or chemical, physical or biological contents. Septic tank pumpings and grease and grit trap waste are excluded. 
Street means any public thoroughfare for the passage of vehicle and pedestrian traffic. 
Stable matter means all manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or about a stable, or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure and resulting from the keeping of animals, livestock or poultry. The owner, operator or producer of such waste shall be free to compost, disperse or otherwise transport such waste providing such activity does not conflict with any ordinance, law or regulation governing such activity. If the owner, operator or producer of such waste utilizes a bin, dumpster or roll-off container for storage and transport of such waste the storage and transport will be performed by the permittee under terms, prices and documents acceptable to the owner or operator or producer and the city and the permittee; provided that such storage, transport or disposal does not conflict with any ordinance, law or regulation. 
Temporary C&D waste means temporary use of roll-off containers for the collection, transportation and disposal (including recycling and reuse) of C&D debris in accordance with TCEQ regulations. 
Temporary C&D waste activities means the collection, transportation and disposal (including recycling and reuse) of C&D debris through the use of collection vehicles, containers, or the use of roll-off containers in accordance with TCEQ regulations and this chapter. The construction or remodeling activity is temporary in nature; meaning that when the construction or remodeling activity is finished the collection vehicle will be immediately removed from the site. 
Vegetable waste means putrescible solid waste resulting from the processing of plants for food by commercial establishments such as canneries. 
Vehicle means any wheeled conveyance. 
Waste material means all nonhazardous, solid waste (including garbage, rubbish, commercial, industrial and institutional refuse, bulky waste, yard waste and recyclable materials) generated that is not excluded by this chapter. Waste material shall not include any excluded waste. 
Yard waste means grass, leaves, flowers, stalks, stems, tree trimmings, branches, and tree trunks. For yard waste collection services, grass, pine needles, leaves, flowers, stalks, stems, and small tree trimmings (less than three (3) feet in length and less than two (2) inches in diameter) shall be in the cart(s) for regular weekly residential collection. During semi-annual bulky waste collection, yard waste may be placed in bags, boxes or bundles tied with string or rope not to exceed three (3) feet in length or thirty-five (35) pounds in weight per box, bag or bundle. Permittee shall be obligated to collect no more than four (4) cubic yards of material from any residential unit during the semi-annual bulky waste collection events. Any collections needed by a residential unit in excess of such amount must be individually contracted by the residential unit producer. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-2, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2011-O-08C, § 1, 8-16-2011; Ord. No. 2011-O-11C, § II.1, 12-6-2011; Ord. No. 2018-O-02C, § II, 2-6-2018 ) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 21-2. - Container specifications. 
(a)  Number. Every person occupying a residential unit or commercial producer and every owner of a multifamily use, commercial, industrial or institutional use shall maintain such premises with a sufficient number of solid waste containers or receptacles to provide for the peak output of municipal solid waste from those premises. A resident may collect and transport or contract with a third party, other than the permittee, for the removal and proper disposal of yard wastes such as grass clippings, leaves, prunings and similar waste normally associated with lawn maintenance activities. 
(b)  Garbage and recycling containers. The permittee shall provide each residential unit with a 96-gallon capacity wheeled lidded cart for once-per-week trash collection. All trash must be in the cart provided that, on the collection day following a holiday, a volume equal to the cart, which is bundled, boxed or bagged outside the cart, will be collected as part of that weekly service. Each residential unit will be provided with an 18-gallon recycling collection bin and provided weekly collection service for recyclables on the same day as regular trash collection. Holidays are defined as New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas as they pertain to collection of solid wastes. 
(c)  Commercial, industrial, municipal and other generators. Commercial, industrial, municipal and other generators will be provided with 96-gallon carts, 300-gallon bins, dumpsters or roll-off containers in sufficient number and size to accommodate efficient storage of solid wastes. Collection will occur at least once per week (on-call dumpsters, every-other-week dumpsters and bins and roll-off containers excepted). 
(d)  Roll-off containers. Roll-off containers will be provided by permittee to permanent commercial or industrial or other generators that produce volumes of solid waste that warrant such large size containers. Roll-off containers and other types of collection vehicles and collection service may be provided by permittee for temporary C&D waste activities, at its discretion, according to the same terms and conditions required of any other producer, licensee or third party authorized herein to provide temporary C&D waste activities.. Loads of heavy, dense material such as dirt, rock or concrete, by example, will be serviced with 20-cubic yard containers. 
(e)  For all other garbage or recycling containers or receptacles not provided by a permittee, all other containers shall be watertight and constructed of a solid and durable grade of metal or plastic. Containers not provided by a permittee shall not be collected or emptied by the city or a permittee. 
(f)  Underground containers. Underground garbage containers are prohibited for use in the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-3, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2011-O-08C, § 2, 8-16-2011; Ord. No. 2011-O-11C, § II.2, 12-6-2011)  
Sec. 21-3. - Collection regulations. 
(a)  General. It shall be the duty of every occupant, owner and producer to comply with the regulations regarding the proper disposal of garbage, solid waste, rubbish and waste defined in this chapter and shall adhere to the disposal and collection requirements of this chapter or be subject to the penalties described in section 1-9 (general penalty for violations of Code; continuing violations; abatement; culpable mental state) of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Location of carts, bins, containers, bags, bundles and bulky waste for collection. Each cart(s) or recycling bin, (container, bag, bundle or bulky waste during semi-annual bulky collection events) shall be placed within three (3) feet of the curbside for collection. Curbside refers to that portion of right-of-way adjacent to paved or traveled city roadways (including alleys). Carts and recycling bins shall not be placed within five (5) feet of any mailbox, automobile, utility meter or box, fire hydrant, under overhead wires or under low-hanging tree limbs. Carts, bins, containers, bags, bundles and bulky waste shall be placed within three (3) feet of the curb or the edge of the roadway without interfering with or endangering the movement of vehicles or pedestrians. When construction work is being performed in the right-of-way, carts, bins, containers, bags, bundles and bulky waste shall be placed as close as practicable to an access point for the collection vehicle. Permittee may decline to collect any container, bag, bundle or bulky waste not placed in accordance with these requirements or any waste material not in a container, bin, dumpster, roll-off container, bag or bundle (some bulky items such as furniture excepted). 
(c)  Handicapped residential units. Permittee shall provide special assistance with the collection of their cart, at no additional cost, for those residential units which meet the definition of handicapped residential units, and if such units have submitted written notice of such special need and it has been confirmed by the city. 
(d)  Semi-annual bulky waste collection. Semi-annual bulky waste collection is limited to not more than four (4) cubic yards of material per residence per collection event. Any collection needed by a residential unit in excess of such amount must be contracted by the residential unit producer with permittee under terms, prices and documents acceptable to the residential unit producer, the city and the permittee. 
(e)  Compliance. Every owner, occupant, or producer shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Each cart(s) or recycling bin shall be properly placed the night before day of collection after 6:00 p.m. or the day of collection no later than 5:00 a.m. 
(2)  Each cart(s) or recycling bin should be cleaned by the producer on a regular basis. 
(3)  Each cart(s) or recycling bin should not be filled so that it overflows and is subject to spillage. 
(4)  Each cart(s) or recycling bin must be stored within the property no later than 10:00 p.m. on the day of collection. 
(5)  No cart(s) or recycling bin shall be removed or switched from the assigned address unless it is performed by, or with the permission of, the city or the permittee. 
(6)  Excluded waste shall not be deposited in any cart(s), container, bin or recycling bin. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-4, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2012-O-08A, § II, 8-21-2012)  
Sec. 21-4. - Multifamily, commercial, industrial and institutional refuse. 
The collection and removal of solid waste materials from multifamily, commercial, industrial and institutions, as defined in this chapter, shall be performed by permittee. Refuse, garbage and recyclables may only be deposited in the type and size of containers provided by permittee and upon payment of the applicable fee. The placement of containers for collection from multifamily, commercial, industrial and institutional producers shall be determined by the permittee and the owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-5, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-5. - Collection and removal of dead animals. 
The bodies of large dead animals shall not be placed in carts, bins or other solid waste containers or in any street, alley, easement or public way. The collection and removal of dead animal bodies weighing more than ten (10) pounds shall not be a service of the city or provided by the city's waste disposal contractor. Persons requiring disposal of large dead animals shall be responsible for contacting an appropriate disposal company and making arrangement for disposal on their own. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-6, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-5.5. - Additional work separately contracted at permittee's election. 
Permittee may provide waste collection and disposal service, and/or recyclables collection services, for waste volumes or types not normally generated, including special waste, according to individual agreements negotiated between permittee and such customers and under such terms and conditions as may be mutually agreed upon by permittee, the city and such customers. 
(Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-6. - Certain solid waste materials not handled by city. 
Excluded waste, as defined herein, will not be collected and removed by the city or permittee as a regular service, and each producer generating excluded waste shall dispose of such waste only in accordance with all applicable laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-7, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-6.5. - Temporary C&D debris. 
(a)  The collection, transportation and removal of temporary C&D debris, as defined in this chapter, shall be performed by open competition which may include permittee, the producer, a licensee or other third party. Any rates charged for such services shall not be subject to any franchise fees paid to the city. C&D debris shall be collected and deposited into temporary collection vehicles, trailers, or roll-off containers provided by the producer, permittee, licensee or other third party in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The placement of the temporary containers or roll-offs for collection of the C&D debris shall be determined by the hauler and the owner or occupant and located solely on the owner or occupant's property. No container, vehicle or roll-off shall be placed on any public right-of-way. All pertinent provisions of section 21-3, collection regulations, shall apply to any hauler of such waste, as well as the provisions of section 21-16, regulations pertaining to temporary C&D activities. 
(b)  Storage, collection and transportation activities related to temporary C&D debris may be performed by the producer, permittee, licensee, or other third party as follows: 
(1)  The construction or remodeling activity is temporary in nature; meaning that when the construction or remodeling activity is finished the collection vehicle, roll-off or container will be immediately removed from the site; and 
(2)  The producer, permittee, or licensee responsible for the removal, transport or disposal of debris from the temporary C&D activity will, at the completion of the construction, remodeling or demolition activity, provide the city with a receipt from a legal, permitted or licensed disposal or recycling facility clearly indicating that the load(s) of debris was properly disposed. Persons or entities conducting temporary C&D services and that are not required to obtain a license in accordance with subsection 21-16(g) are not required to provide evidence of disposal hereunder. 
(c)  Other third party as used in this section includes but is not limited to contractors that satisfy the criteria in section 21-16 herein, individual homeowners and individual business owners. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-08C, § 3, 8-16-2011; Ord. No. 2011-O-11C, § II.3, 12-6-2011)  
Sec. 21-7. - Charges for sanitation service—Procedures. 
(a)  Method of charging and billing. The method of charging and billing for sanitation services shall be as follows: 
(1)  All solid waste collection and disposal charges and fees, except for excluded waste and temporary C&D debris and commercial accounts collected by permitee, shall be billed through the accounting and billing mechanics of the department of water and sewer utilities, in a manner which will show each customer's fees and charges separately from the water bill. The charges and fees established and authorized in this section shall be billed to the party in whose name the water service connection is taken where the premises are served with water or sewer and shall be billed to the party in control of the premises at other locations, and if this fact cannot be ascertained, the bill shall be directed to the record owner of such premises. The party who is so billed and to whom services are made available shall be indebted to the city for such services and shall be obligated to make payment thereof as provided in this section. The bill will become delinquent fifteen (15) days after it is rendered. For the purpose of this section, "party" shall mean person, partnership, corporation, association or any other legal entity. Billing activities may be performed by the permittee using similar procedures. 
(2)  In addition to all other legal remedies available for the collection of a debt, the following actions and remedies are authorized for delinquent payment of the charges authorized in this section: 
a.  The city or permittee may refuse to pick up and dispose of the garbage at the delinquent location; 
b.  The water or sewer service, if any, serving the delinquent premises in question may be shut off and terminated; and 
c.  A penalty of ten (10) percent of the total net bill shall be charged in the event of delinquency. 
(3)  All collections by the water and sewer utilities department shall be applied first to the water utilities charges, and the customer shall be deemed to have paid such water and sewer utilities charges first in the event any question should arise as to how outstanding balances should be composed and applied. 
a.  All present water and sewer utilities department customers to be billed hereunder shall be automatically placed on the billing for sanitation services charges, regardless of whether or not a written contract exists between the city and such customers. 
b.  All present water and sewer utilities guaranty deposits upon termination of sanitary service or water service may be applied to any amounts due either for sanitation service charges or fees of water and sewer utilities bills. 
c.  All water and sewer utilities services contracts hereafter entered into between that department and the customer shall contain an agreement that any guaranty deposit upon termination of sanitary service or water service may be applied to sanitation service fees and charges and to water utilities charges that have become due. 
(b)  Basis for charge. Establishment of service charges will be based upon the current use of the property rather than being based upon the zoning. 
(c)  Proration. There shall be no proration of service charges for a portion of a billing period. The initial billing shall be made concurrent with the initial water billing. No final billing for sanitation charges for less than a full billing period shall be rendered. 
(d)  Collection. Except as set forth in this section, collection service shall be provided by the city or permittee for all water and sewer customers within the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-8, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2005-O-11B, § I, 11-28-2005; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009; Ord. No. 2011-O-08C, § 4, 8-16-2011)

This rate is for curbside collection, including curbside recycling with an 18-gallon bin and residential bulky pick-up twice a year.

Sec. 21-9.5. - Bins, containers, trucks and any other equipment. 
All bins, containers, trucks and any other equipment that permittee furnishes to each occupant shall remain the permittee's property. Producers shall use the equipment only for its proper and intended purpose and shall not overload (by weight or volume), move or alter the equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2006-O-8B, § III, 9-11-2006; Ord. No. 2007-O-8A, § III, 8-27-2007; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-10. - Deposit fee. 
There shall be charged a deposit fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for residential customers and seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for commercial customers using the city garbage service. 
(Ord. No. 81-O-2B, § IV, 2-10-81; Ord. No. 2005-O-11B, § IV, 11-28-2005; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-11. - When bills due and payable. 
All bills for garbage service are due by the fifteenth (15th) day of each month, after the month for which such service is furnished. If due bills are not paid by the fifteenth (15th) day of the month after such service is furnished, a ten (10) percent penalty will be added to the service bill. 
(Ord. No. 81-O-2B, § V, 2-10-81; Ord. No. 2005-O-11B, § V, 11-28-2005; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-12. - Free service. 
No free service shall be rendered by the city for garbage service. 
(Ord. No. 81-O-2B, § VI, 2-10-81; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-13. - Water customers inside city limits. 
All customers connected to the city water service inside the city limits shall be charged for garbage collection service. 
(Ord. No. 81-O-2B, § VII, 2-10-81; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-14. - Collection and removal of illegally dumped rubbish or trash on private property. 
(a)  Notice to remove. It shall be the duty of the director of public works of the city to notify the owner or agent for management purposes of any private premises within the city upon which any rubbish or trash has been illegally placed or disposed, to remove such rubbish or trash within ten (10) days. Such notice shall be in writing and may be served on the owner or agent by handing it to him in person or by registered/certified mail addressed to such owner or agent at his post office address as shown on the tax rolls of the county, or where such address is not shown, then by notice by publication in a paper of general circulation in the city as many as two (2) times within ten (10) consecutive days, provided that such notice is not necessary when such waste material is determined by the director of public works to be an immediate health hazard. 
(b)  Failure to comply. The failure by either the owner or such agent, as the case may be, to comply with the notice set out in the preceding subsection, shall render such person guilty of a misdemeanor and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which the violation is continued or permitted, and subject the person to the civil and criminal penalties described in section 1-9 (general penalty for violations of Code; continuing violations; abatement; culpable mental state) of the Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  Collection and removal by city. Upon the failure of any such owner or agent to comply with the notice, as set out in this section, or upon the written request and authorization of such owner or agent so notified, or if the director of public works determines that such conditions constitute an immediate health hazard, it shall become the responsibility of the director of public works to have such rubbish or trash materials collected and removed from any property within the city. 
(d)  Recovery of costs by city. A charge for the actual expenses incurred for the collection and removal of rubbish or trash shall be levied, assessed and collected against such property each time such collection and removal of rubbish or trash shall be levied, assessed and collected against such property each time such collection and removal of solid waste materials shall be performed, provided that an additional charge can be levied, assessed and collected against such premises for the actual additional cost for such collection and removal. The charges provided for in this section shall be levied, assessed and collected by the city. If any person shall fail to pay such charges so assessed within thirty (30) days after proper notice, the city administrator shall file, with the county clerk, a statement by the director of public works setting out the expenses that the city has incurred pursuant to the provisions of this section. The city shall thereby perfect a privileged lien on the property involved, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, to secure the expense to the city, together with ten (10) percent interest from the date such payment is due. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-5, § 1-9, 5-14-80; Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § II, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-15. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
The following provisions shall apply to the franchise agreement between the city and any solid waste company that receives a franchise from the City of Marble Falls: 
(1)  Where a contractual provision includes city facilities, such term shall include the pavilion located at 307 Buena Vista. 
(2)  Whenever newspaper notice is required by a contractual provision related to the franchise agreement between the city and a solid waste company that receives a franchise, such notice shall be through the city's designated newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2009-O-07A, § IV, 7-27-2009)  
Sec. 21-16. - Regulations pertaining to temporary C&D activities. 
(a)  Regulations. Except as provided in subsection (g), all individuals or entities, including permittee, who desire to participate in waste collection services for temporary C&D activities shall be required: 
(1)  To obtain an annual construction and demolition debris hauler's license issued by the city. 
(2)  To maintain their collection vehicles, containers, load security tarps, and other equipment in good condition and working order and that all debris is transported in leak proof containers and be fitted/constructed so that the C&D debris is kept covered at all times except when being loaded and emptied; 
(3)  To maintain commercial general liability and property damage, automobile liability and worker's compensation insurance in accordance with, at minimum, the requirements set by Marble Falls; 
(4)  To provide evidence of specific safety training for each of its operators; 
(5)  To provide evidence of proper disposal at disposal sites that are permitted by TCEQ regulations for such disposal or through recycling or reuse efforts; and 
(6)  Identify each vehicle or container the licensee operates within the city by placing clearly legible letters identifying the name of the person or business responsible for the operation of the motor vehicle or container. 
(b)  License application. An application for the construction and demolition debris hauler's license shall be made on forms provided by the city for that purposes along with any application fee. The application requires that the applicant: 
(1)  State the name under which the applicant/owner/operator will conduct business within the city, the business address, and the telephone number. 
(2)  State the make, model, body style and license plate of each motor vehicle to be used in the city. 
(3)  Submit any other information reasonably required by the city to administer this section. 
By submitting the application, the applicant/owner/operator agrees to abide by and be bound by the provisions and regulations of the city's ordinances and to comply with all other state and federal laws applicable to the licensee's activities. Upon proper application, a construction and demolition debris hauler's license will be issued in the name of the person or entity responsible for the operation of the motor vehicle(s) used for C&D debris hauling within the city. 
(c)  Authorization and modifications. The license authorizes only the name on the license to operate such business within the city. A licensee must notify the city of any change in the information submitted in its application for a licensee, including change in the name, address or telephone number of the licensee or in the motor vehicles being operated within the city. Should licensee sell such business, the new owner/operator shall be required to obtain a new license in that owner/operator's name. The notification of change must be given to the city in writing within ten (10) days of the change. 
(d)  Term. The license is valid for a term of one (1) year, unless earlier revoked. 
(e)  Suspension or revocation. The city manager or his designee may suspend or revoke a construction and demolition debris hauler's license, for good cause shown, after notice and hearing. Good cause shall include: 
(1)  Any material misrepresentation in the application for the license or any fraud in its procurement; 
(2)  Any cause which would have prevented the granting of the license in the first place; 
(3)  Misconduct of the licensee, such as the violation of this section or any other provision of the city's ordinances or state law; 
(4)  The violation of any of the conditions of the license issued under this section. 
(5)  Failure to provide evidence of proper disposal of C&D waste. 
If the license is revoked for illegal dumping or hauling, the license may only be restored with the approval of the city manager and payment of a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) renewal after revocation fee. 
(f)  License fee. Each person granted a license under this section must pay a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus ten dollars ($10.00) for a tag for each motor vehicle or container used or operated within the city. 
(g)  Persons and temporary C&D activities exempt. Persons and entities that perform temporary C&D activities are exempt from the requirements of this section 21-16 so long as the temporary C&D activities meet the following conditions: 
(1)  The project for which the temporary C&D services are performed is related to new construction of a residential structure or a remodel of an existing residential structure that does not exceed two thousand nine hundred (2,900) square feet of remodeled area; or 
(2)  The project for which the temporary C&D services are performed is related to new construction of a commercial structure with a footprint that does not exceed twelve thousand (12,000) square feet or a remodel of a commercial structure that does not exceed twelve thousand (12,000) square feet of remodeled area; and 
(3)  The project for which the temporary C&D services are performed is not a demolition activity. Demolition is defined as construction, reconstruction or the tearing down of a project or structure that requires more than sixty (60) percent of the building or structure to be reconstructed or removed; and 
(4)  The collection vehicle/container used by the person or entity providing the temporary C&D services is a rubber tire trailer or truck with a total capacity not exceeding eighteen (18) cubic yards and is not a roll-off type container of any size. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-08C, § 6, 8-16-2011; Ord. No. 2011-O-11C, § II.4, 12-6-2011) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-O-11C, § II.4, adopted Dec. 6, 2011, amended § 21-16 title to read as herein set out. Former § 21-16 title pertained to regulations pertaining to temporary C&D debris haulers.  
Sec. 21-17. - Brush disposal. 
(a)  Each resident within the city limits will receive curbside pickup of general brush and yard waste at no charge during the regularly scheduled time. The pick-up schedule and frequency will be set by the city and may be amended from time to time as determined by the city. The scheduled time for pick up may include a time frame of up to seven (7) days within which the pick-up will occur. 
(b)  Brush intended to be picked up must be piled at the curb/edge of street and within five (5) feet of the curb and be in place prior to the first scheduled day of pickup in order to guarantee pickup at no charge. Brush placed at the curb after the first day of the assigned week for the pick-up is not guaranteed to be picked up without charge. 
(c)  Residents and property owners who wish to have brush picked up at a time other than the regularly scheduled time may contact the city and request pick up for a fee. The fee will be assessed on the monthly utility bill or submitted in the form of an invoice to the resident and/or property owner. 
(d)  In addition to curb side pick-up, the city will provide a designated brush drop-off location, with posted hours of operation to be determined by the city, for residents and property owners at no charge. The designated drop-off location will be available to contractors or commercial firms for a fee. 
(e)  The city may adopt reasonable fees as described in the Master Fee Schedule, Appendix C, of this Code, which may be amended from time to time for reimbursement of costs associated with the services provided as part of the brush management program, which costs may include, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Brush disposal. Fees for non-residents, contractors or commercial firms utilizing the city designated brush drop-off location. 
(2)  Brush pick-up. Fees assessed on the resident or property owner's monthly utility bill for pick-up of brush that is not placed at curbside in time for the regularly scheduled pickup. 
(3)  Fees and charges described herein may be combined or separated and shall be billed and collected as generally described in section 21-7. 
(4)  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in section 21-17. These fees relate solely to the matters covered by section 21-17 and are separate from all other fees, fines, and penalties chargeable by the city. 
(5)  The city manager or his/her designee may, at any time, elect to waive fees assessed for curbside brush pickup or assessed at the designated drop-off site. 
( Ord. No. 2018-O-02C, § II, 2-6-2018 )  
Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
