St. art. 1105b. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Obstruction of drainage ditches. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fill up or otherwise obstruct any drainage ditch on or along any street or alley in the city. 
(Ord. No. 32-O-6(8), § 1, 6-7-32)  
Secs. 22-2—22-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CLOSING OF STREETS AND ALLEYS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Chapter 22, Article II, §§ 22-16—22-24, was deleted as being superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, adopted Nov. 23, 1999, included herein as a new Art. II., §§ 22-16—22-15. Former Art. II, §§ 22-16—22-24, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 91-O-1A, adopted Jan. 17, 1991. 
 
Sec. 22-16. - Reference to City Charter. 
Provisions for the closing of streets and alleys are also provided in section 10.12 of the City Charter. The procedures and regulations set out herein are consistent with the requirements of the Charter and set out additional regulations to be followed in the closing of streets and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-17. - Public hearing generally. 
The city council, on its own initiative, may call a public hearing to determine whether or not any street or alley in the city, or any portion thereof, should be closed or abandoned as a public thoroughfare. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-18. - Petition for hearing. 
The city council shall be required to call a public hearing on the closing of any street or alley, or any portion thereof, upon receipt by the city secretary of a petition, meeting the requirements set out herein, requesting such hearing, from any person or entity (hereinafter referred to as petitioner) owning property adjacent to such street or alley section to be closed. The petition must legally describe that portion of the street or alley to which the request for abandonment applies, specifically state that all people signing the petition fully support the requested closure and it must be signed by at least twenty-five (25) registered voters of the city. The name and address of each person signing the petition must be clearly and legibly printed next to the signature. The Charter provisions regulating examination, certification, and amendment of initiative petitions shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-19. - Nonrefundable fee to be paid in advance. 
Before any action is taken, the petitioner shall pay the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) in advance to cover the expenses of processing the request. This sum of money shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-20. - Recommendation of the planning and zoning commission. 
Before city council may take final action to adopt any ordinance to close a street or alley the planning and zoning commission shall review the request from the point of view of impact on the future traffic circulation in the city and shall make a recommendation on such matters to the city council. The planning and zoning commission shall not be required to conduct a public hearing and their action may be taken after the city council has conducted its public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-21. - Public hearing. 
The city council shall conduct a public hearing not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the certification of the petition for the primary purpose of discussing the proposed abandonment. Written notice of the public hearing shall be sent to all owners of real property, as indicated by the most recently approved municipal tax roll, within two hundred (200) feet of the street or alley to be closed no less than eleven (11) days before the public hearing. In addition, notice of the public hearing shall be published in two (2) consecutive issues of the official newspaper of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-22. - Appraisal of real property required. 
Within ninety (90) days after the city council public hearing and planning and zoning commission recommendation, but before city council final action, the petitioner shall provide an appraisal by a certified appraiser of real property. The cost of the appraisal is to be paid in full by the petitioner. Upon written application by the petitioner stating the need therefor, this time period may be extended by the city manager. Such extension shall be in writing. 
The petitioner may elect, in writing, to utilize the average appraised values of the land immediately adjacent to the street or alley to be closed as shown on the most recent approved municipal tax roll. Such average value shall be calculated by city staff. 
If the requested closure is approved by city council, the actual selling price shall be determined solely by the city council, but in no case shall the selling price be less than the appraised value as determined under this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-23. - Action by city council. 
No street or alley shall be closed except by ordinance adopted and approved by no less than five (5) affirmative votes of the city council. Such ordinance shall include a description of the street or alley to be abandoned in relation to adjacent lots and blocks along with a map showing the location of the street or alley and adjacent lots. No ordinance affecting the closure of a street or alley shall become effective until thirty (30) days after the passage of the ordinance. 
If, during such thirty-day period, a referendum petition is presented to the city secretary which in all respects conforms to the referendum provisions of Article 6 of the Charter, and same is found sufficient, then the secretary shall certify the sufficiency of same to the city council, and an election shall be called submitting the question of whether or not the sale or lease shall be consummated. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-24. - Replat required. 
Unless otherwise approved by council, when the abandonment of a street or alley results in lots that do not front upon an improved street, said lots shall be replatted so that all resulting lots have frontage upon an improved street. Said replat shall be presented to and approved by the planning and zoning commission and city council within nine (9) months of the date of the ordinance abandoning said street or alley or the ordinance abandoning the street or alley shall become null and void. Should said ordinance become null and void the purchase price paid for the abandoned street or alley shall be refunded to the petitioner. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Sec. 22-25. - Appeals. 
Any person deciding to appeal the decision of the city council to a court of competent jurisdiction, shall do so within ten (10) days after enactment of the ordinance closing the street or alley, or portion thereof, and if no appeal is taken within such ten-day period, then the ordinance shall never be questioned in any court of this state. 
(Ord. No. 99-O-11B, § II, 11-23-99)  
Secs. 22-26—22-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FRANCHISE OPERATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Franchises generally, App. A. 
 
Sec. 22-41. - Fee for use of public property without franchise agreement. 
On the first day of May of each year, any person occupying or using the streets, highways, rights-of-way, easements, alleys, parks or other public property owned by the city within the corporate limits of the city without a franchise agreement from the city shall, as a condition to further occupancy, pay to the city annually for such use and privilege, a rental equal to two (2) percent of the gross receipts received by such person from his business conducted within the city for the preceding year or any portion of the preceding year during which such time such operations were carried on. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 1, 4-13-76)  
Sec. 22-42. - Exemption. 
This article shall not apply to any person who is presently operating under any franchise agreement with the city or who is obligated by franchise or other contract to pay a greater rate than specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 2, 4-14-76)  
Sec. 22-43. - Sworn report of gross proceeds. 
Every person using the streets, highways, rights-of-way, easements, alleys, parks or other public property or using any telegraph, telephone, electric light or other pole, gas or water pipelines, other pipelines or any other types of fixtures or appurtenances which are affixed thereon, shall, on the first day of April of each year, file with the city secretary a sworn report showing the gross receipts from the business conducted by such person for the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 3, 4-13-76)  
Sec. 22-44. - Examination of books, records. 
The city council may, when it sees fit, have the books and records of any person required to pay the rental charge imposed by this article examined by a representative of the city to ascertain whether the statement filed in accordance with this preceding section is accurate. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent the city from ascertaining the facts by other methods. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 4, 4-13-76)  
Sec. 22-45. - Authorization to use public property. 
Upon receipt of the rental charge imposed by this section, the city secretary shall deliver to the person paying the same a receipt therefor, which receipt shall authorize such person to use and occupy the streets, highways, rights-of-way, easements, alleys, parks and other public property of the city in carrying on its business for twelve (12) months from such date. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 5, 4-13-76)  
Sec. 22-46. - Rental charge additional to ad valorem taxes and other taxes. 
The rental charge provided for in this article is not charged as a tax but is made for the privilege enjoyed by the person upon whom it is imposed of using the streets, highways, rights-of-way, easements, alleys, parks and other public property of the city in the conduct of their businesses. Such charge is additional to all ad valorem and franchise taxes and to all taxes of every nature imposed on such person. 
(Ord. No. 76-O-4A, § 6, 4-13-76)  
Chapter 24 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes saved from repeal, § 1-6(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements in assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-6(8); administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Taxation generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. Title 122, Vol. 20; Property Tax Code, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, for the purpose of this article, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, are defined as follows: 
Consideration means the cost of the room, sleeping space, bed or other facility in a hotel and shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room, sleeping space, bed or other facility for occupancy. 
Hotel means any building, trailer or other facility in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration. The term hotel shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to use or possession of any room, sleeping space, bed or other facility in a hotel for any purpose. 
Occupant means anyone who for a consideration uses, possesses or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms, sleeping space, beds or other facility in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement. 
Permanent resident means any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or sleeping space or other facility in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the current calendar year or preceding year. 
Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating managing or controlling any hotel. 
Quarterly period means the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March; the second quarter being the months of April, May and June; the third quarter being the months of July, August and September; and the fourth quarter being the months of October, November and December. 
Tax collector means the city secretary or her designated agent or agencies. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 1, 1-12-82) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Secs. 24-2—24-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LOCAL SALES AND USE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Local Sales and Use Tax Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1066c. 
 
Sec. 24-16. - Imposed. 
The majority of the qualified voters having voted for the adoption of the local sales and use tax, the tax is hereby imposed in the city and shall become effective as provided in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1066c. 
(Ord. No. 67-O-12A, § II, 12-18-67)  
Sec. 24-17. - On receipts from sale, etc., of gas and electricity. 
The city, by majority vote of its city council, hereby votes to retain the taxes authorized by the Local Sales and Use Tax Act (Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art 1066c) on the receipts from the sale, production, distribution, lease or rental of, and the use, storage, or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use, as authorized by section 6 of House Bill No. 1, Acts 1978, 65th Legislature, Second Called Session. 
(Ord. No. 79-O-4, § 1, 4-10-79)  
Secs. 24-18—24-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Occupancy tax authorized, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1269j—4.1. 
 
Sec. 24-31. - Levy; rate; exceptions. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any room or space furnished by any hotel where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day. Such tax shall be equal to seven (7) percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room to such hotel. 
(b)  No tax shall be imposed under this article upon a permanent resident. 
(c)  No tax shall be imposed under this article upon a corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
(d)  No tax shall be imposed under this article upon the United States government and its employees, including military personnel, traveling on official business. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 2, 1-12-82; Ord. No. 85-O-11C, § 1, 11-26-85; Ord. No. 96-O-11A, 11-26-96)  
Sec. 24-32. - Collection. 
Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel located within the incorporated boundary or extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city shall collect the tax imposed in section 24-31 for the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 3, 1-12-82; Ord. No. 2004-O-7B, § I, 7-26-2004)  
Sec. 24-33. - Reports. 
On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required to collect the tax imposed by this article shall file a report with the tax collector showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of tax collected on the city's behalf on such occupancies and any other information as the tax collector may reasonably require. Such person shall pay over the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. There shall also be furnished to the tax collector at the time of payment of such tax, a copy of the quarterly tax report filed with the state comptroller in connection with the state hotel occupancy tax. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 4, 1-12-82)  
Sec. 24-34. - Rules and regulations. 
The tax collector shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied in this article and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 5, 1-12-82)  
Sec. 24-35. - Violations. 
If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed in this article, make reports as required and pay to the tax collector the tax imposed in this article, shall fail to collect such tax, shall fail to file such report, or shall fail to pay such tax, or if such person shall file a false report, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 6, 1-12-82)  
Sec. 24-36. - Penalties. 
If any person shall fail to file a report as required in this article or shall fail to pay to the tax collector the tax as imposed in this article when such report or payment is due, he shall forfeit five (5) percent of the amount due as a penalty and after the first thirty (30) days he shall forfeit an additional five (5) percent of such tax; provided, however, that the penalty shall never be less than one dollar ($1.00). Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum beginning sixty (60) days from the date due. 
(Ord. No. 82-O-1C, § 7, 1-12-82)  
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, adopted Sept. 20, 2011, repealed former Ch. 25, §§ 25-1—25-255, and enacted a new Ch. 25 as set out herein. Former Ch. 25 pertained to the same subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation of chapter. 
Cross reference— Any ordinance prescribing specific traffic and parking regulations applying to certain streets saved from repeal, § 1-6(12); placing handbills on vehicles prohibited, § 3-21; operation of motor vehicles and parking in cemeteries, § 7.5-5; emergency medical services vehicle, Ch. 9; junked vehicles, § 13-41 et seq.; offenses, Ch. 14; police, Ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 22; development code, App. B.; Operation of motor vehicles and parkin in cemeteries, § 7.5-5. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 25-1. - Adoption by reference of state laws concerning operation and movement of vehicles. 
The provisions of Chapter 545 of the Texas Transportation Code, as amended, concerning operation and movement of vehicles are adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-2. - Scope. 
The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer exclusively to the operation of vehicles upon streets except: 
(1)  Where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. 
(2)  Where otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-3. - Compliance with chapter. 
It is unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-4. - Obedience to traffic officers. 
No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer, or in the case of fire or other emergency any fire department official, given to direct or control traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-5. - Application of chapter—To pushcarts, animal-drawn vehicles, etc. 
Every person propelling any pushcart or riding any animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-6. - Rights of owners of real estate. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the owner of real property used by the public for purposes of vehicular travel by permission of the owner and not as matter of right from prohibiting such use, or from requiring other or different or additional conditions than those specified in this chapter, or otherwise regulating such use as may seem best to such owner. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-7. - Parties to violation. 
Every person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit or aids or abets in the commission of, any act declared in this chapter to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, whether individually or in connection with one (1) or more other persons or as a principal, agent or accessory, shall be guilty of such offense; and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or willfully induces, causes, coerces, requires, permits or directs another to violate any provision of this chapter is likewise guilty of such offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-8. - Responsibility of owners, employers, etc. 
It is unlawful for the owner or any other person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle to require or knowingly to permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street in any manner contrary to law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-9. - Municipal court fee. 
(a)  Defensive driving course administrative fee. The municipal court of the City of Marble Falls, Texas, shall charge a fee in the maximum amount permitted by state law from every person requesting a defensive driving course and dismissal of certain misdemeanor offense charges. 
(b)  Collection and deposit of fees. 
(1)  Collection of fee. The municipal court clerk or the municipal judge shall collect the entire defensive driving course administrative fee at the time a person enters a plea either in person or in writing of no contest or guilty and presents to the court an oral or written request to take a defensive driving course. 
(2)  Deposit of fee. The municipal court clerk or the municipal judge shall deposit all defensive driving course administrative fees collected into the municipal treasury and credited solely to the budget allocated for the municipal court for any given fiscal accounting year. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-10. - Municipal court building security fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court building security fund (the "fund"). 
(b)  The municipal court of the City of Marble Falls (the "municipal court") is hereby authorized and required to assess a municipal court building security fee (the "fee") in the amount permitted by state law against all defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense by the municipal court. Each misdemeanor offense shall be subject to a separate assessment of the fee. 
(c)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person receives community supervision, including deferred adjudication; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(d)  The municipal court clerk is hereby authorized and required to collect the fee and to pay same to the treasury of the City of Marble Falls, Texas. All Fees so collected and paid over to the treasury of the City of Marble Falls, Texas shall be segregated into the fund. 
(e)  The fund shall be used only for the purposes authorized by article 102.017 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as it may be amended from time to time, for financing security personnel for the municipal court or to finance items when used for the purpose of providing security services for the building or buildings housing the municipal court. 
(f)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city council of the City of Marble Falls, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-11. - Municipal court technology fund. 
(a)  Establishment of municipal court technology fund. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund (the "technology fund"). 
(2)  The technology fund may be maintained in an interest bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(b)  Establishment of amount of the fee and assessment and collection. 
(1)  The fee shall be in the maximum amount permitted by state law. 
(2)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
a.  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
b.  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred disposition community supervision; or 
c.  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(3)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after the adoption of this chapter. 
(4)  The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the finance director of the City of Marble Falls, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology fund. 
(c)  Designated use of the fund and administration. 
(1)  The technology fund shall be used only for the purposes authorized by article 102.0172 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, as it may be amended from time to time, for financing the purchase of or maintaining technological enhancements for the Municipal Court of the City of Marble Falls, Texas. 
(2)  The technology fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Council of the City of Marble Falls, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Secs. 25-12—25-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 25-31. - Police officers—Duty to enforce traffic laws. 
It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to enforce all street traffic laws of the state and city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-32. - Same—Authority to direct traffic. 
Officers of the police department and fire department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal, provided that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department and fire department may direct traffic as conditions may require. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-33. - Arrest without warrant. 
Any peace officer is hereby authorized to arrest without warrant any person found committing a violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Secs. 25-34—25-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES AND MARKINGS 
 
Sec. 25-46. - Generally. 
(a)  All traffic control devices erected, installed or used for the purpose of regulating, warning, guiding or controlling traffic within the corporate limits of the City of Marble Falls, Texas, shall be uniform and shall be located, as far as practicable, in conformity with the latest edition of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices or its successor, as it may be approved by the Texas Department of Transportation. 
(b)  A "traffic control device" is a sign, signal, marking, or device that is: 
(1)  Consistent with the Texas Transportation Code; 
(2)  Placed or erected by the city or other public body having jurisdiction; and 
(3)  Used to regulate, warn or guide traffic. 
(c)  For purposes of this division, the traffic control device designated "No through Truck Traffic" shall mean that it shall be unlawful for any person to operate an overweight vehicle or an oversize vehicle on the designated portion of streets within the city. 
(d)  For purposes of this division, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  The term "overweight vehicle" shall mean any vehicle having a gross vehicular weight of eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds or more. 
(2)  The term "oversize vehicle" shall mean any vehicle having four (4) or more axles. For purposes of this division, the number of axles on a vehicle shall include the axles on any trailer being operated in conjunction with the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-47. - Obedience to traffic-control devices. 
The operator or driver of any animal, animal-drawn vehicle, motor vehicle, motorcycle, bicycle, motor-assisted bicycle, motor driven cycle, moped, or special mobile equipment shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device erected, installed or used in accordance with this division, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the operator of an authorized emergency vehicle permitted by the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-48. - Unauthorized devices. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain, or display upon or in view of any highway, street or alley any unauthorized traffic control device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device, or which attempts to regulate, warn, guide or control the movement of traffic, or which hides from view, interferes with or obstructs the effectiveness of any official traffic control device. 
(b)  No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit commercial advertising upon any official traffic control device. 
(c)  Each and every unauthorized traffic control device herein is declared to be a public nuisance, and the chief of police, his successor or designated representative is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-49. - Unauthorized tampering. 
No person shall without lawful authority attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down, remove or cause to be removed any official traffic control device or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-50. - Failure to comply. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any traffic control device erected pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-51. - Installations by city manager. 
(a)  After the effective date of this division, the city manager shall appoint a traffic control committee made up of persons employed by the city to advise the city manager regarding the location of traffic control devices to be used within the corporate limits of the city. Unless otherwise provided for by law, the city manager shall make final determinations regarding the location of traffic control devices based upon the recommendations of the traffic control committee. 
(b)  The city manager or the city manager's designee shall erect all traffic control devices, as determined pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. A traffic control device erected pursuant to this section shall be an authorized traffic control device of the city. 
(c)  Whenever any traffic control device has been erected pursuant to this section, the city manager shall thereafter provide written notification, which shall be signed by the city manager to the city secretary, stating which type of traffic control device was erected, installed, or put into use, and giving the location and date thereof. The city secretary shall maintain a list of such information among the official papers of the office of the city secretary. 
(d)  In the event of an emergency, as determined by the city manager, the city manager may erect traffic control devices without prior consideration by the traffic control committee. 
(e)  Speed limits, and the city's authority to amend speed limits, are governed by the Texas Transportation Code Section 545.356. Changes to speed limits within the city shall be adopted by the city council in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-52. - Proof of existence of devices. 
Proof of actual existence of any traffic control device purporting to regulate, warn, guide or control the use of any highway, street, or alley, or any activity thereon, by pedestrians or operators or drivers of animals, animal-drawn vehicles, motor vehicles, motorcycles, bicycles, motor-assisted bicycles, motor driven cycles, moped, or special mobile equipment shall constitute prima facie evidence that the same was erected, pursuant to and by the authority granted by this division. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-53. - Traffic movement regulations. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish regulations controlling oversized and/or overweight vehicular traffic driving or operating on certain city streets, roadways or highways, or any segment thereof within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Commercial motor vehicle means a motor vehicle or combination of motor vehicles designed or used primarily to transport property, excluding a passenger bus, passenger automobile, motorcycle, panel delivery truck or pickup truck. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle that is self-propelled. 
Oversize vehicle means any vehicle having four (4) or more axles. For purposes of this section, the number of axles on a vehicle shall include the axles on any trailer being operated in conjunction with the vehicle. 
Overweight vehicle means any vehicle having a gross vehicular weight of eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds or more. 
Semi-trailer means every vehicle of the trailer type so designated or used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of its own load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
Trailer means a vehicle that is designed or used to carry a load wholly on its own structure; and is drawn or designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
Truck means a commercial truck, semi-trailer, trailer, truck-tractor, cement mixer, or any combination thereof. 
Truck-tractor means a motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing another vehicle; and not constructed to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load to be drawn. 
Vehicle means a device in or by which a person or property is or may be transported or drawn on a public highway, including motor vehicles, commercial motor vehicles, trucks, truck-tractors, cement mixers, trailers, and semi-trailers, other than a device used exclusively on stationary rails or tracks. 
(c)  Restrictions. Except as provided by the exemptions contained herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate an oversized and/or overweight truck or vehicle, truck-tractor, semi-trailer, or any combination thereof upon any municipal street designated as a "no through truck street" within the corporate city limits of the city. 
(d)  Exemptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to oversized or overweight vehicles that are: 
(1)  Owned, leased, used or in service to the city, the county, the state or the United States; 
(2)  School buses and public buses; 
(3)  Emergency vehicles in route to and returning from an emergency, including any wrecker or tow trucks; 
(4)  Making home deliveries or pickups of goods or services to a residence located on said street; 
(5)  Making business deliveries to or pickups from a business or construction site located on said street; 
(6)  Travel trailers, boats and recreational vehicles; 
(7)  Owned or used in the service of public utilities when in the performance of their duties; or 
(8)  Vehicles operating under a valid permit issued by the Texas Department of Transportation under the applicable provision in the Transportation Code. 
(e)  Through truck traffic shall be prohibited on the following streets and such streets are hereby designated as "No Through Truck Traffic" streets: 
(1)  Main Street District: 
a.  Main Street from Buena Vista to Sixth Street. 
b.  Fifth Street from US 281 to Avenue J. 
c.  Fourth Street from US 281 to Avenue J. 
d.  Third Street from US 281 to Avenue J. 
e.  Avenue H from US 281 to Buena Vista. 
f.  Second Street from US 281 to Avenue J. 
g.  First Street from US 281 to Avenue H. 
h.  First Street from Main Street to Avenue J. 
i.  Yett Street from Avenue H to Avenue J. 
(2)  Avenue F and Avenue G: 
a.  Avenue F from FM 1431 to Twelfth Street. 
b.  Avenue G from FM 1431 to Twelfth Street. 
(3)  Northwest Segment: 
a.  Northwood Drive from Pony Drive to US 281. 
b.  Bluebonnet Drive from Pony Drive to Northwood Drive. 
c.  Lantana Drive from Bluebonnet Drive to US 281. 
d.  Mission Hills Drive from Bluebonnet Drive to US 281. 
e.  Avenue K from Mission Hills Drive to FM 1431. 
f.  Avenue J from US 281 to FM 1431. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 2019-O-09A , § II, 9-17-2019)  
Secs. 25-54—25-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL RULES OF VEHICLE OPERATION  
DIVISION 1. - SPEED AND RELATED MATTERS 
 
Sec. 25-91. - Maximum limits. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a motor vehicle upon any city street or roadway in Marble Falls at a greater rate of speed than thirty (30) miles per hour, except at the locations stated below. 
(1)  School zones—per section 25-92. 
(2)  The maximum speed limit on the following streets shall be twenty (20) miles per hour. 
a.  Cedar Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
b.  Ash Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
c.  Mulberry Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
d.  Hackberry Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
e.  Live Oak Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
f.  Pecan Drive—from Pecan Valley Drive to Orchard Drive. 
g.  Vista Drive—from Cedar Drive to Pecan Drive. 
h.  Orchard Drive—from Cedar Drive to Pecan Drive. 
i.  Avenue J—from Backbone Creek Bridge to Johnson Street. 
j.  Johnson Street—from Avenue L to Pecan Valley Drive. 
k.  Pecan Valley Dr.—from Johnson St. south two hundred (200) feet. 
l.  Esperanza Avenue—from West FM 2147 to La Ventana Drive. 
m.  Alegria Circle—from Esperanza Avenue to end. 
n.  La Ventana Drive—from South US 281 to Bendito Way. 
o.  Corazon Drive—from Max Starcke Dam Road to Bendito Way. 
p.  Bendito Way—from Corazon Drive to end. 
q.  Cielo Circle—from Bendito Way to end. 
r.  Elclavar Circle—from Bendito Way to end. 
(3)  The maximum speed limit on the following street shall be thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
a.  Mormon Mill Road—from US 281 to the North city limit. 
(4)  The maximum speed limit on the following street shall be forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
a.  Manzano Mile—from the 2200 block South to its intersection with RM1431. 
(5)  Construction zones. The maximum speed limit in a construction zone shall be set by the city manager or the city manager's designee. A "construction zone" is a portion of a highway or street where road construction, maintenance or utility work activities are occurring and that is marked by signs indicating that it is a construction zone, indicating where the zone begins and ends, and stating: "Fines double when workers present." 
(6)  The maximum speed limits on US 281 shall be as follows: 
FOR NORTHBOUND TRAFFIC 
a.  Beginning at milepoint 37.850 (SH 71) to milepoint 36.273 (1.571 miles North of SH 71), a distance of 1.577 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of sixty-five (65) miles per hour. 
b.  From milepoint 36.273 (1.577 miles North of SH 71) to milepoint 34.550 (one thousand one hundred fifty-one (1,151) feet South of Mark Starke Dam Rd.), a distance of 1.723 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of fifty-five (55) miles per hour. 
c.  From milepoint 34.550 (one thousand one hundred fifty-one (1,151) feet South of Mark Starcke Dam Rd.), to milepoint 34.182 (three hundred fifty (350) feet South of Gateway Central), a distance of 0.368 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
d.  From milepoint 34.182 (three hundred fifty (350) feet South of Gateway Central), to milepoint 32.462 (676 feet North of RM 1431), a distance of 1.595 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
FOR SOUTHBOUND TRAFFIC 
e.  Beginning at milepoint 32.462 (six hundred seventy-six 676 feet North of RM 1431) to milepoint 34.182 (three hundred fifty (350) feet South of Gateway Central), a distance of 1.595 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
f.  From milepoint 34.182 (three hundred fifty (350) feet South of Gateway Central), to milepoint 34.550 (one thousand one hundred fifty-one (1,151) feet South of Mark Starke Dam Rd.), a distance of 0.368 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of forty-five (45) miles per hour. 
g.  From milepoint 34.550 (one thousand one hundred fifty-one (1,151) feet South of Mark Starke Dam Rd.), to milepoint 36.273 (1.577 miles North of SH 71), a distance of 1.723 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of fifty-five (55) miles per hour. 
h.  From milepoint 36.273 (1.577 miles North of SH 71), to milepoint 37.850 (SH 71), a distance of 1.577 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of sixty-five (65) miles per hour. 
(7)  The school speed zones on RM 1431 shall be as follows: 
FOR EASTBOUND TRAFFIC 
From mile-point 11.087 to mile-point 11.396, a distance of 0.309 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of twenty-five (25) miles per hour when flashing. 
FOR WESTBOUND TRAFFIC 
From mile-point 11.396 to mile-point 11.087, a distance of 0.309 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of twenty-five (25) miles per hour when flashing. 
(8)  The maximum speed limits on SH-71 shall be as follows: 
FOR EASTBOUND TRAFFIC 
From five thousand three hundred one (5,301) feet west of US 281, at mile point 2.254 (Marble Fall's west city limit) to two thousand two hundred thirty-nine (2,239) feet east of US 281, at mile point 3.682 (Marble Fall's east city limit), a distance of 1.428 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of sixty (60) miles per hour. 
FOR WESTBOUND TRAFFIC 
From two thousand two hundred thirty-nine (2,239) feet east of US 281, at mile point 3.682 (Marble Fall's east city limit) to five thousand three hundred one (5,301) feet west of US 281, at mile point 2.254 (Marble Fall's west city limit), a distance of 1.428 miles, a prima facie maximum speed limit of sixty (60) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 2015-O-09D, § II, 10-6-2015 ; Ord. No. 2016-O-07A, § II, 7-19-2016 ; Ord. No. 2016-O-08A, § II, 8-16-2016 )  
Sec. 25-92. - School zones. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle of any kind or description at a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour in any school zone within the city as may be marked or designated as such during the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., whenever such school is in session, unless the speed limit or time is otherwise posted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-93. - Signs. 
Whenever the speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour, as prescribed by section 25-91, is, by the provisions of this division or other ordinance of the city council, increased or decreased at any intersection or other place or upon any part of a street, the city manager or their designee shall erect appropriate signs giving notice of such speed limit. No such limit shall be effective unless such signs are erected. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Secs. 25-94—25-135. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TURNING OR STOPPING MOVEMENTS 
 
Sec. 25-136. - Prohibited turns at intersections. 
(a)  Pursuant to the traffic control committee process established in section 25-51, the city manger or their designee is hereby authorized, to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on the signs or they may be removed when such turns are permitted. 
(b)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such signs. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Secs. 25-137—25-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING 
 
Sec. 25-181. - Parallel, angle parking. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this section. On one-way streets, vehicles may be parked on the left side of the street, with the left-hand wheels within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, unless signs prohibit parking. 
(b)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(c)  Whenever parking spaces are marked by lines on the pavement, whether for parallel or angle parking, a vehicle must be parked entirely within the lines of the parking space. 
(d)  Pursuant to the traffic control committee process established in section 25-51, the city manger or their designee, shall determine upon which streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal-aid or state highway within this city unless the state highway engineer has determined that the street is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street or upon any railway tracks. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-182. - Heavy vehicles and equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for a person owning or operating motor vehicles or equipment of eighteen thousand (18,000) pounds gross vehicular weight rating or over to park such a vehicle or piece of equipment on city-owned and-maintained streets within the city limits unless such vehicle or piece of equipment is actively engaged in delivering a product or service at the location at which it is parked. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-183. - Parking restricted in residential districts. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Commercial vehicle means every vehicle, including motor vehicles and trailers, designed, maintained or used primarily for the nonrecreational transportation of property and/or people and the gross weight of which exceeds seven thousand (7,000) pounds. This definition shall never be construed to include motor vehicles commonly known as "pickup trucks". 
Pole trailer means every vehicle, not a trailer or semitrailer (as defined above) designed to be drawn by another vehicle and attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach or pole, or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle and ordinarily used for transporting long or irregular shaped loads such as poles, pipe or structural members capable generally of sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections. 
Recreational vehicle means every motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer primarily designed and used as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, including motor homes, truck campers, travel trailers, and camping trailers. 
Residential district means any area within the city zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, R-5, RE-1, RA-1, RT-3, MH-1, MH-2 or MH-3. 
Semitrailer means every vehicle design for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some or part of its weight or load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
Tractor trailer means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so constructed as to carry a load other than part of the weight and load so drawn. 
Trailer means every vehicle, designed or used to carry its load wholly on its own structure and for being drawn by a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Parking prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a service vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, pole trailer, truck tractor, recreational vehicle or boat on a street in a residential district or on a street bordering a residential district, except as authorized in section 7-295. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in accordance with the general penalty provisions found herein. 
(d)  Exceptions. The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Trucks and trailers designed and used for transporting furniture and household goods while in the process of loading or unloading said items. 
(2)  Other trailers or commercial vehicles while in the process of loading or unloading. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 2012-O-08B, § 14, 11-20-2012)  
Secs. 25-184—25-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PEDESTRIANS 
 
Sec. 25-201. - Adoption by reference of state law concerning pedestrian conduct. 
The provisions of Chapter 552 of the Texas Transportation Code, as amended, concerning pedestrian conduct are adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Secs. 25-202—25-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES AND PLAY VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 25-221. - Adoption by reference of state law concerning bicycles and play vehicles. 
The provisions of Chapter 551 of the Texas Transportation Code, as amended, concerning operation of bicycles, mopeds and play vehicles are adopted by reference and made a part of this Code as if set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)  
Sec. 25-222. - Skateboards, roller skates, roller blades, and scooters. 
(a)  No person shall operate a skateboard, roller skate, roller blade, pocket bike, mini-motorbike or scooter on the 100, 200, 300, 400 block of Main Street. 
(b)  This section does not apply to a motorized wheelchair or nonmotorized mobility device. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-09D, § II, 9-20-2011)

ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Plumbing code, § 7-56 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-16. - Conduct in vicinity of treatment plant. 
Within an area one hundred (100) yards from the intakes into the city water treatment plant on Lake Marble Falls, no person shall: 
(1)  Bathe, swim or wade; 
(2)  Throw or place in the water any waste or refuse or any substance or thing which may contaminate the water; 
(3)  Throw or place such waste, refuse, substance or thing within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the banks of the water or within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the normal high water mark of the water; or 
(4)  Keep or bring any animal within such distance from the banks of the water or the normal high water mark (except animals passing over a public road), or wash or clean within such distance thereof any vehicle which has been used for the transportation of any animal. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-7, Art. I, 7-22-80)  
Sec. 26-17. - Wasting. 
No person shall water any grass, tree or plant in such manner that water from the city water system flows into the roadway of any street or alley. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-7, Art. II, 7-22-80)  
Sec. 26-18. - Proclamation restricting use. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to issue proclamations from time to time as the amount of available water justifies, imposing or withdrawing any or all of the following restrictions on the use of water from the city's distribution system in all or any part of the city as circumstances may require: 
(1)  No person shall water any grass, tree or plant for a period of up to seven (7) days. Plants which cannot be kept alive without daily watering may be watered from vessels but not by use of a hose when watering is prohibited. 
(2)  Water may not be run into "fill and draw" swimming pools, that is, pools not provided with filtration, pumping and chemical feeding equipment so that the water may be continuously reused. 
(3)  Motor vehicles may not be washed. 
(4)  No person shall use water for crop irrigation or stock watering unless from individual storage and water sources. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-7, Art. III, § 1, 7-22-80) 
Cross reference— Drought contingency plan, § 26-48 et seq.  
Sec. 26-19. - Inserting choke. 
After warning by the city against excessive use of water, if the owner or occupant of any property shall violate any such restriction while the same is in effect, whether convicted in court thereof or not, the city may insert a choke in the service pipe to such property so as to cut down the water supply to an amount necessary for ordinary cooking, drinking and washing purposes. 
(Ord. No. 80-O-7, Art. III, § 3, 7-22-80)  
Secs. 26-20—26-30. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - WATER WELLS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Water wells, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 28.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Backflow preventer means a device or means to prevent backflow into the city's potable water system. 
Cross connection means a physical connection between the city's potable water supply system and any other water system, including water from wells other than the city's wells. 
Existing work means a water well or water system which had been installed prior to September 11, 1984. 
Plumbing inspector means any person employed by the city for the purpose of inspecting work and installations in connection with health and safety laws as provided in, or referred to in, this division. The plumbing inspector shall be licensed by the Texas State Board of Plumbing Examiners in accordance with the Plumbing License Law of 1947, as amended (Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243—101). 
Public sewer means a common sewer directly controlled by public authority. 
Sanitary sewer means a pipe which carries waste water and excludes storm and surface water and groundwater. 
Septic tank means a watertight receptacle which receives the discharge of a drainage system or part thereof, which is designed and constructed so as to separate solids from the liquid, digest organic matter through a period of detention, and allow the liquids to discharge into the soil outside of the tank through a drainfield or disposal or perforated piping. 
Water main means a water-distribution pipe for public or community use. 
Water wells means bored wells; dug wells and driven wells are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § IV, 9-11-84) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-32. - Intent and purpose. 
For the protection and preservation of life and of the public health, safety, property and general welfare of the people, the following provisions are enacted relating to the construction of water wells and water systems in the city and outside the city, if same be connected to either the city water or sewerage system. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § III, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-33. - Permits and licenses generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a water well or water system, as set out in this division without having first procured the necessary licenses and permits as provided for in this division. All workmanship and materials shall meet the requirements of this division in regard to the drilling construction, location and operation of such wells and systems. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § II, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-34. - Licensing requirements. 
Construction of water wells shall be performed only by those holding a valid water well drillers license issued by the state. The license number shall be displayed during construction at the site of the work. The number shall be clearly readable from the nearest traveled public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § V, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-35. - Permit, fees and inspections. 
(a)  When permit required. It shall be unlawful to construct a water well or major overhaul of a water well without first securing a water well permit. The driller or work over contractor shall secure written indemnity of the city from the person who has commissioned the well drilling or work over of an existing well before work may commence. 
(b)  When permit not required. Permits are not required for routine maintenance and for existing work. 
(c)  Permits not transferable. Each permit issued under this section shall be personal to the permittee. No such permit shall be assigned or transferred to another person and no person shall permit another person to obtain a permit in his name or permit any new well construction or major overhaul work to be performed under his permit by any person other than a person authorized to do the same. 
(d)  False statement or bad faith. Any person who shall wilfully make any false statement in order to obtain a permit shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty provided in section 1-9. Bad faith or unreasonable delay in the performance of work under this division shall be deemed a sufficient reason for suspension of the permit of the well driller so offending and no further permit shall be issued until such act of bad faith or unreasonable delay has been corrected. 
(e)  Issuance of permit: The plumbing inspector or his designated representative shall issue all plumbing permits in accordance with the provisions and requirements of this division. All application for permits shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the well driller; 
(2)  Number of well drillers license; 
(3)  Name, address and telephone number of property owner; and 
(4)  Sketch of property that shows location of the water well, all buildings, septic tanks, drain fields and other significant structures. The sketch shall also show the location of structures on adjacent property if within ten (10) feet of the property line. 
(f)  Duration of permits. Every permit issued under the provisions of this section shall expire ninety (90) days after the date thereof unless the work authorized by such permit shall have been commenced within such time; every permit shall expire if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for as long as ninety (90) days after it has been commenced. In every case where a permit is permitted to expire, a new permit shall be obtained before any work is resumed. 
(g)  Permit and inspection fees. The permit and inspection fees provided in this subsection shall be paid to the city before the issuance of a permit and before any work is started. The fees shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(h)  Inspections and tests. The plumbing inspector shall have the right to enter the property for the purpose of inspections to ensure compliance with this division. In addition, the plumbing inspector shall have the right to enter the property at any time in the future for the purpose of inspections to ensure that there are no cross-connections. Upon completion of the well, the well driller shall furnish the plumbing inspector a copy of the drillers log and a copy of the water analysis. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VI, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-36. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  Casing. A casing of steel or other approved material shall be provided to prevent caving of the formations penetrated and also to ensure protection of water supply from contamination by water from shallow strata. The wall shall be cased from the bottom of the drilled hole to eighteen (18) inches above the finish grade or more if required to keep surface water from entering casing. 
(b)  Well seal. The annular space between the drilled hole and the well casing shall be sealed with concrete or grout for a depth of at least ten (10) feet below finished grade. The casing shall be covered at the ground with a concrete slab no less than twenty-four (24) inches by twenty-four (24) inches by twelve (12) inches. The top of this slab shall protrude six (6) inches above finished grade and shall be sloped away from the casing. The top of the casing shall be provided with a suitable well seal to prevent contamination of the well. If a vent is provided on the casing it shall be equipped with an elbow turned downward and screened with a 16-mesh screen. 
(c)  Disinfection of wells and equipment. Upon completion of the well, but before it is placed into service, the well and equipment shall be disinfected by the use of chlorine (powdered, tablet or solution). 
(d)  Water samples. After the chlorine has been flushed, a sample of water shall be analyzed for purity. The well shall not be placed into service until the water has been tested and found to be suitable for human consumption. 
(e)  Abandonment of wells. Permanently abandoned wells shall be filled with cement grout or concrete. Abandoned wells shall not be used for the disposal of waste water, septic tank effluent or other wastes. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VII, 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-37. - Applicability of state regulations. 
The regulations of the Texas Department of Water Resources and the Texas Water Well Drillers Act as they pertain to the construction of water wells shall be and are hereby incorporated into this division. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(A), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-38. - Domestic use. 
No more than one (1) household may be served by a single water well if the water is for use inside the house. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(B), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-39. - Commercial use. 
It shall be unlawful for a commercial water well to be used for domestic (household) use or for consumption by the public. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(C), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-40. - Location. 
Water wells shall be constructed no closer to property lines or significant structures than the following distances: 
(1)  Front property line: 25 feet; 
(2)  Side property lines: 5 feet; 
(3)  Rear property lines: 10 feet; 
(4)  Buildings: 5 feet; 
(5)  Power lines: 30 feet; 
(6)  Septic tanks and drain fields: 150 feet; 
(7)  Barns and animal pens: 150 feet; 
(8)  Permanent derricks and towers: No closer than 40 feet to side property lines. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(D), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-41. - Sewer charges. 
The city is required to charge for water discharges into the public sewer on the basis of actual quantity of water discharge into the sanitary sewer. The method of determining this quantity is based on estimates made from the water meter readings; therefore, when a water well is being used the following shall apply: 
(1)  Water well used only for yard watering and other uses not connected with the sanitary sewer: No change in sewer charges is required. 
(2)  Residential water wells used in such a manner that all or a portion of the well water enters the public sewer: Sewer charge shall be based on a minimum of ten thousand (10,000) gallons a month discharged entering the sanitary sewer. 
(3)  Water wells used for purposes other than residential use where all or a portion of the well water enters the public sewer: The person being charged for sewer has the following options: 
a.  Water being discharged into the sanitary sewer will be estimated by the city based on each individual case; or 
b.  A waste water meter shall be installed and maintained by the city, but all costs incurred by the city will be charged to the person using the public sewer. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(E), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-42. - Cross connections. 
There shall be no physical connection between water from water wells and the city's water mains. The use of valves, check valves, backflow preventers, etc., as a means of connecting the water systems is prohibited. There shall be a physical separation of at least nine (9) inches (air gap) between systems. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(F), 9-11-84)  
Sec. 26-43. - Debris, etc., on public rights-of-way. 
There shall be no debris, dirty water, mud or other refuse dumped or discharged onto public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 84-O-9A, § VIII(G), 9-11-84)  
Secs. 26-44—26-47. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - DROUGHT CONTINGENCY PLAN[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, adopted March 18, 2014 , amended div. 3, §§ 26-48—26-54, in its entirety. Former div. 3 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Ord. No. 2013-O-07D, § II, adopted August 6, 2013. 
Cross reference— Emergency management, Ch. 8; proclamation restricting use, § 26-18. 
 
Sec. 26-48. - Declaration of policy, purpose, and intent. 
In order to conserve the available water supply and protect the integrity of water supply facilities, with particular regard for domestic water use, sanitation, and fire protection, and to protect and preserve public health, welfare, and safety and minimize the adverse impacts of water supply shortage or other water supply emergency conditions, the city adopts the following regulations and restrictions on the delivery and consumption of water. 
Water uses regulated or prohibited under this drought contingency plan (the plan) are considered to be nonessential and continuation of such uses during times of water shortage or other emergency water supply condition are deemed to constitute a waste of water which subjects the offender(s) to penalties as defined in section 26-53 of this plan. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-49. - Public education. 
The city will periodically provide the public with information about the plan, including information about the conditions under which each stage of the plan is to be initiated or terminated and the drought response measures to be implemented in each stage. This information will be provided by means of town meetings, press releases and utility mass mailings. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-49.1. - Authorization. 
The Mayor or his/her designee for the City of Marble Falls is hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this plan upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect public health, safety, or welfare. The mayor or his/her designee shall have the authority to initiate or terminate drought or other water supply emergency response measures as described in this plan. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-49.2. - Application. 
The provisions of this plan shall apply to all persons, customers, and property utilizing water provided by the city. The terms "person" and "customer" as used in the plan include individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, and all other legal entities. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-50. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this plan, the following definitions shall apply: 
Aesthetic water use means water use for ornamental or decorative purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and water gardens. 
Commercial and institutional water use means use which is integral to the operations of commercial and nonprofit establishments and governmental entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants, and office buildings. 
Conservation means those practices, techniques, and technologies that reduce the consumption of water, reduce the loss or waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of water so that a supply is conserved and made available for future or alternative uses. 
Customer means any person, company, or organization using water supplied by city. 
Domestic water use means water use for personal needs or for household or sanitary purposes such as drinking, bathing, heating, cooking, sanitation, or for cleaning a residence, business, industry, or institution. 
Industrial water use means the use of water in processes designed to convert materials of lower value into forms having greater usability and value. 
Landscape irrigation use means water used for the irrigation and maintenance of landscaped areas, whether publicly or privately owned, including residential and commercial lawns, gardens, golf courses, parks, and rights-of-way and medians. 
New landscape is defined as vegetation: 
(1)  Installed at the time of new construction of a residential or commercial facility; 
(2)  Installed as part of a governmental entity's capital improvement project; 
(3)  Installed to stabilize an area disturbed by construction; and/or 
(4)  That alters more than five hundred (500) contiguous square feet of an existing landscape. 
Nonessential water use means water uses that are not essential or required for the protection of public, health, safety, and welfare, including: 
(1)  Irrigation of landscape areas, including parks, athletic fields, and golf courses, except otherwise provided under this plan; 
(2)  Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motorbike, boat, trailer, airplane or other vehicle; 
(3)  Use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, or other hard-surfaced areas; 
(4)  Use of water to wash down buildings or structures for purposes other than immediate fire protection; 
(5)  Flushing gutters or permitting water to run or accumulate in any gutter or street; 
(6)  Use of water to fill, refill, or add to any indoor or outdoor swimming pools or Jacuzzi-type pools; 
(7)  Use of water in a fountain or pond for aesthetic or scenic purposes except where necessary to support aquatic life; 
(8)  Failure to repair a controllable leak(s) within a reasonable period after having been given notice directing the repair of such leak(s); and 
(9)  Use of water from hydrants for construction purposes or any other purposes other than firefighting. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-51. - Criteria for initiation and termination of drought response stages. 
(a)  The mayor or his/her designee shall monitor water supply and/or water demand conditions on a daily/weekly basis and shall determine when conditions warrant initiation or termination of each stage of the plan, that is, when the specified "triggers" are reached. 
(b)  The triggering criteria described below are based on current capacities of the city's water plant and distribution system. 
(c)  Stage 1 Triggers—MILD Water Shortage Conditions. 
Requirements for initiation. 
Customers shall be requested to voluntarily conserve water and adhere to the prescribed restrictions on certain water uses, defined in section 26-50, definitions, when (either, any of) the following condition(s) exist or as determined by the mayor or his/her designee. 
A.  When, the combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan reaches 1.4 million acre-feet, pursuant to requirements specified in the city's wholesale water purchase contract with the Lower Colorado River Authority (L.C.R.A.) and notification is received from L.C.R.A. requesting initiation of Stage 1 of the drought contingency plan. 
B.  When total daily water demand equals or exceeds eighty-seven (87) percent of plant capacity for three (3) consecutive days or eighty-eight and one-half (88.5) percent of plant capacity on a single day. 
C.  Continually falling treated water reservoir levels that do not refill above ninety (90) percent overnight. 
D.  Region-wide drought caused by widespread, long term shortages. 
Requirements for termination. 
Stage 1 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of three (3) consecutive days; or as determined by the Mayor or his/her designee. 
(d)  Stage 2 Triggers—MODERATE Water Shortage Conditions. 
Requirements for initiation. 
Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses provided in section 26-50, definitions, of this plan when any of the following condition(s) exist: or as determined by the mayor or his/her designee. 
A.  When, pursuant to requirements specified in the city wholesale water purchase contract with L.C.R.A. and notification from L.C.R.A. is received requesting initiation of Stage 2 of the drought contingency plan. 
B.  When total daily water demand equals or exceeds ninety (90) percent of plant capacity for two (2) consecutive days of ninety-one and one-half (91.5) percent of plant capacity on a single day. 
C.  Continually falling treated water reservoir levels that do not refill above eighty (80) percent overnight. 
D.  Region-wide drought caused by widespread, long term shortages. 
Requirements for termination. 
Stage 2 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of three (3) consecutive days: or as determined by the mayor or his/her designee. Upon termination of Stage 2, Stage 1 becomes operative. 
(e)  Stage 3 Triggers—SEVERE Water Shortage Conditions. 
Requirements for initiation. 
Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements and restrictions on certain nonessential water uses for Stage 3 of this plan when any of the following condition(s) exist: or as determined by the Mayor or his/her designee. 
A.  When, combined storage of Lakes Travis and Buchanan reaches six hundred thousand (600,000) acre-feet in accordance with the LCRA DCP, or the LCRA Board declares a drought worse than the drought of record and a mandatory curtailment of firm water supplies, and notification is received requesting initiation of Stage 3 of the drought contingency plan. 
B.  When total daily water demand equals or exceeds ninety-five (95) percent of plant capacity for two (2) consecutive days of ninety-six (96) percent of plant capacity on a single day. 
C.  Continually falling treated water reservoir levels that do not refill above seventy-five (75) percent overnight. 
D.  Region-wide drought caused by widespread, long term shortages. 
Requirements for termination. 
Stage 3 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of three (3) consecutive days, or as determined by the Mayor or his/her designee. Upon termination of Stage 3, Stage 2 becomes operative. 
(f)  Stage 4 Trigger—CRITICAL Water Shortage Conditions. 
Requirements for initiation. 
Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements and restrictions for Stage 4 of this plan when the mayor or his/her designee, determines that a water supply emergency exists based on: 
A.  When, pursuant to requirements specified in the city's wholesale water purchase contract with L.C.R.A. notification is received requesting initiation of Stage 4 of the drought contingency plan. 
B.  Major water line breaks, or pump or system failures occur, which cause unprecedented loss of capability to provide water service; or 
C.  Natural or manmade contamination of the water supply source. 
D.  Region-wide drought caused by widespread, long term shortages. 
Requirements for termination: 
Stage 4 of the plan may be rescinded when all of the conditions listed as triggering events have ceased to exist for a period of three (3) consecutive days, or as determined by the Mayor or his/her designee. 
(g)  Stage 5 Trigger—EMERGENCY Water Shortage Conditions. 
Requirements for initiation. 
Customers shall be required to comply with the requirements and restrictions for Stage 5 of this plan when the Mayor or his/her designee, determines that a water supply emergency exists based on: 
A.  When, pursuant to requirements specified in the city's wholesale water purchase contract with LCRA notification is received requesting initiation of Stage 5 of the drought contingency plan. 
B.  Major water line breaks, or pump or system failures occur, which cause unprecedented loss of capability to provide water service; 
C.  Natural or manmade contamination of the water supply source. 
D.  Region-wide drought caused by widespread, long term shortages; or 
E.  Any other emergency water supply or demand conditions that the L.C.R.A. constitutes a water supply emergency or is associated with a prolonged drought worse than the drought of record requiring the mandatory curtailment of firm water supplies at a level more severe than in Stage 4. 
Requirements for termination: 
The water treatment plant capacity condition listed above as a triggering event for Stage 5 has ceased to exist for five (5) consecutive days; or if L.C.R.A. announces that mandatory water restrictions for firm water customers are no longer required. 
( Ord. No. 2014-O-03A, § II, 3-18-2014 ; Ord. No. 2019-O-08E , § II, 8-20-2019)  
Sec. 26-52. - Drought response stages. 
(a)  The Mayor or his/her designee, shall monitor water supply and/or demand conditions on a daily basis and, in accordance with the triggering criteria set forth in section 26-51 of this plan, shall determine that a mild, moderate, severe, critical, emergency or water shortage condition exists and shall implement the following notification procedures. 
(b)  Notification. 
(1)  Notification of the public: The city manager or his/her designee shall notify the public by means of: 
a.  Publication in a newspaper of general circulation. 
b.  Direct mail to each customer. 
c.  Public service announcements. 
d.  Signs posted in public places. 
(2)  Additional notification: The city manager or his/her designee shall notify directly, or cause to be notified directly, the following individuals and entities: 
a.  Mayor/chairman and members of the city council/utility board. 
b.  Fire chief(s). 
c.  City and/or county emergency management coordinator(s). 
d.  County judge and commissioner(s). 
e.  State disaster district/department of public safety. 
f.  TCEQ (required when mandatory restrictions are imposed). 
g.  Major water users. 
h.  Critical water users, i.e. hospitals. 
i.  Parks/street superintendents and public facilities managers. 
j.  Wholesale supplier (notify when mandatory restrictions are imposed). 
[(c)  Stages.] 
(1)  Stage 1 Response—MILD Water Shortage Conditions. 
Goal: Achieve a voluntary five (5) percent to ten (10) percent reduction in daily water demand. 
Supply management measures: In order to manage limited water supplies and/or reduce water demand, the city will: 
• Reduce or discontinue flushing of water mains, 
• Audit your utility system for water loss, 
Voluntary water use restrictions: 
Water customers are requested to voluntarily limit the irrigation of landscaped areas by irrigating landscapes only between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 10:00 a.m. and between 7:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on designated outdoor water use days. Customers with even-numbered street addresses may water on even-numbered days of the month, and customers with odd-numbered street addresses may water on odd-numbered days of the month. 
(2)  Stage 2 Response—MODERATE Water Shortage Conditions.
